details.name: Early Life and Political Journey
details.description: The Prime Minister, Shri Lal Bahadur Shastri was born on 2 October, 1904 at Mughalsarai in Uttar Pradesh. ‘Shastri’ was the honorific awarded to him upon graduation, and became an indelible part of his name.

details.name: Green Revolution
details.description:
"In 1964, despite 17 years of independence, India was still trapped in a devastating food crisis. Self-sufficiency in food production was still a distant dream; wheat was being imported from America since 1959. A massive drought multiplied the enormous challenge of providing food for the poor and the marginalized.
Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri took command. He knew that before he could end the misery, he had to lift the nation’s morale. His answer was emphatic: Self-reliance tomorrow could only be achieved by self-sacrifice today.
He demanded austerity from the privileged. A stark message was sent out on 15 August 1964:
(CG – 15 August 1964, Red Fort)
Speech: “If millions of farmers of our country resolve to increase the yield of agriculture together as a movement, the situation will change for better.” 

Lavish feasts, the indulgence of the rich, must end, said the Prime Minister. They did. 
Speaking over All-India Radio, the Prime Minister requested every fellow citizen to give up one meal a week. The people accepted, willingly.
He encouraged homemakers to cook nutritious meals without rice and wheat, of which there was a huge shortage. His appeal was respected. 
The Prime Minister cultivated crops in the lawn of his bungalow as an example in the grow-more-food campaign.
Jai Jawan, Jai Jawan, Jai Kisan, Jai Kisan
Indians responded to their leader’s call with national zeal and emotional unity. It was a tribute to Shastri’s inspirational leadership.
On the administrative side, Prime Minister Shastri regulated the price and distribution of food grains. Food from surplus states like Punjab, Orissa, Madhya Pradesh and Andhra Pradesh was rushed to the food deficit states.
A long-term answer required more. It was vital to increase the national agricultural output.
He established four major institutions: 
1. The Food Corporation of India, through which the state started sourcing foodgrains directly from farmers, reducing their dependency on middlemen.
2. The Agricultural Prices Commission, which, for the first time, introduced a minimum support price [MSP] for farmers.
3. The Durgapur Fertilizer Factory, to reduced dependency of this crucial input from imports.
4. The Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR), which developed the science for India’s agricultural sector. Scientists taught farmers methods to accelerate wheat and paddy cultivation through new seeds, techniques and fertilisers.
On 10 October 1965 Prime Minister Shastri wrote a letter to the farmers of India and urged them to boost the crop yield.
His slogan was: “If one Maund in 65, then one and a quarter Maund in 66”.
These visionary decisions led to what is known as the Green Revolution. Today, India is a food-surplus nation.

details.name: White Revolution
details.description: The White Revolution was led by Prime Minister Shri Shastri in order to make the country self-sufficient in milk and other dairy products. The aim was realised thanks to efforts such as cattle feed factories and milk producer cooperatives.

details.name: Nuclear Policy
details.description: The Prime Minister, Shri Shastri believed in developmental use of nuclear technology. While speaking at the opening of a plutonium plant at Trombay, he regretted that nuclear energy was being weaponised.

details.name: Economic Initiative
details.description: The Prime Minister Shri Shastri focused on an overall development of the economy. His initiatives resulted in an increase in national income as well as increased industrial and agricultural productivity.

details.name: Language Agitation
details.description: In order to settle down the Tamil movement against the introduction of Hindi as an official language, Shri Lal Bahadur Shastri insisted on the importance of national unity over all other concerns.

details.name: Foreign Policy
details.description: The Prime Minister, Shri Lal Bahadur Shastri reaffirmed the traditional contours of nuclear disarmament, international collaboration, and world peace in his foreign policy.

details.name: Jai Jawan Jai kisan
details.description: After having achieved success on both fronts, the agrarian crisis and the aggression by Pakistanis, Shastriji gave to the nation the slogan "Jai Jawan! Jai Kisan!" on October 21st, 1965, at Urwa Maja near Prayagraj.

details.name: The War of 1965
details.description:
On 24 April 1965 Pakistan opened a second, and unusual, war front. Its tanks and artillery penetrated upto 10 kms in the Kutch region of the Gujarat state.
The Indian Army retaliated in strength. Fighting was sporadic, but the outcome was decisive. A subdued Pakistan was forced to withdraw and accept a ceasefire on 30 June 1965.
This proved to be the opening act of a larger aggressive scenario.
In early August 1965, Pakistan’s forces crossed into Jammu and Kashmir, repeating their old tactics of invasion through deceit. About 10,000 armed intruders crossed the Line of Control, in an attack codenamed “Operation Gibraltar”.
Pakistan had, once again, underestimated the unity of Indian people and their determination to repel the invader. The shepherds of Kashmir brought the first information about these infiltrators to Indian security forces and helped in the mop-up process.
The Indian Army, following up with hard action, cleared infiltrators from the vitally important Kargil heights, and secured the Srinagar-Leh Road. In a dramatic victory, the Indian Army captured the strategic Haji Pir Pass.
Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri mobilized the people, inspiring an outpouring of support for the country’s war effort. Women generously donated their jewellery to the defence fund.
An anxious Ayub Khan, having watched Operation Gibraltar collapse, moved to the next stage of his war plan.
On 1 September, Pakistan attacked in brigade strength, with armour and artillery, in Chhamb, Jammu, in a bid to capture Akhnoor with its regular troops. Operation Grand Slam had begun. Their objective was to take Jammu and Kashmir.
Prime Minister Shastri sent a directive to India’s Army chief, General J.N. Chaudhuri, to “deliver a befitting reply to the enemy”.
India responded with a sweeping attack.

At 3:30 in the morning of 6 September Shri Lal Bahadur Shastri startled a watching world, disoriented Pakistan and shifted the course of war with a remarkable strategic counter offensive as Indian troops advanced through the international border, crossed the Ichhogil Canal and reached the vicinity of Lahore airport.
Pakistan threw the full range of its resources into what was now the “All-Out War”.
The next day, on 7 September, Pakistan’s paratroopers attempted to sabotage Indian airfields. Most were killed, the rest captured.
It was now time for a clearly desperate Pakistan to deploy their trump card – the powerful Patton tank.
Pakistan made its most ambitious move in Punjab. On 8 September, its First Armoured Division, which included 100 of the latest American Patton tanks, and 11th Infantry Division breached the Punjab border and reached Khem Karan, five kilometres away, threatening the road to Amritsar.


Indian Forces were heavily outnumbered in tank strength, but immensely superior in tactical response.
They took up a horseshoe position at Asal Uttar. The Indian commanding officer at Asal Uttar, Lieutenant General Harbaksh Singh, knew his terrain, full of sugarcane fields. He flooded the sugarcane fields to slow down the advancing Pattons.
At 8 AM on 10 September, Pakistan opened a heavy artillery barrage; an hour later its heavy Pattons rumbled forwards. Their progress became lumbered as many got stuck in the mud. Indian troops opened heavy fire, decimating the armoured offensive.
The valour of India’s selfless, outnumbered battalions remains a narrative of sacrifice, heroism and triumph in India’s military annals. The highest honour, Param Vir Chakra, was awarded to Havaldar Abdul Hamid, who destroyed a total of five Pattons from his anti-tank jeep, and died while pursuing a sixth one.
Lt. Col Ardeshir Burjorji Tarapore was also posthumously awarded Param Vir Chakra.
This was the biggest tank battle since the Second World War. Defeat at Asal Uttar broke the spine of Pakistan’s offensive.
Asal Uttar became famous as the graveyard of Pakistan’s Patton tanks. The wrecked Patton tanks became an enduring symbol of Pakistan’s historic defeat.
In the skies, Gnats of the Indian Air Force made their reputation against Pakistan’s American supplied Sabres. On 11 September, the Indian Air Force pulverized Pakistan’s biggest airbase at Sargodha.
Ayub Khan, waking up to reality, realized that his forces were on the point of defeat. He asked China for help.
On 17 September, Prime Minister Shastri, speaking in Parliament, accused China of fabricating stories to stoke tension. But Beijing soon went silent. Pakistan’s generals realized that China was not going to enter war on behalf of a third party.
Pakistan had been comprehensively routed, when United Nations Secretary General U Thant visited Delhi and requested an end to hostilities. India declared a ceasefire on 22 September.
In a petty and bloodthirsty display of frustration, Pakistan bombed thickly-populated areas of Amritsar in two raids, killing 77 civilians, hours before silencing its guns.
The war paused at 3:30 AM on 23 September. Lal Bahadur Shastri and our Defence Forces had stood as the shield of the nation’s integrity.
“Jai Jawan... Jai Jawan... Jai Kisan…
Jai Kisan... Jai Hind... Jai Hind”
The political debris of war is untidy, strewn with immediate problems and long-term demands; so India accepted an offer by the Soviet Union to mediate between India and Pakistan. A peace conference was scheduled for 4 to 10 January 1966 in the capital of Uzbekistan, Tashkent.

details.name: The Tashkent Agreement 1966
details.description:
Prime Minister Shastri left for Tashkent on 3 January 1966 with a strong Indian delegation that included Defence Minister Y.B. Chavan and Foreign Minister Swaran Singh. प्रधानमंत्री शास्त्री 3 जनवरी 1966 को एक मजबूत भारतीय प्रतिनिधिमंडल के साथ ताशकंद के लिए रवाना हुए जिसमें रक्षा मंत्री वाई.बी. चव्हाण और विदेश मंत्री स्वर्ण सिंह भी शामिल थे।
Field Marshal Ayub Khan, accompanied by his Foreign Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, headed the Pakistani delegation. पाकिस्तानी प्रतिनिधिमंडल का नेतृत्व कर रहे थे फील्ड मार्शल अयूब ख़ान और उनके साथ थे उनके विदेश मंत्री ज़ुल्फ़िकार अली भुट्टो।
The chief Soviet intermediary was Premier Aleksey Nikolayevich Kosygin. प्रमुख सोवियत मध्यस्थ प्रीमियर अलेक्सी निकोलायेविच कोसिगिन थे।
Prime Minister Shastri arrived on 4 January, and soon made it clear that India’s sovereignty over Jammu and Kashmir was non-negotiable. The state would always remain an integral part of India. Ayub Khan was left with no option but to accept India’s position on Kashmir. The next morning, Prime Minister Shastri and Field Marshal Ayub Khan held one-to-one discussions.
प्रधानमंत्री शास्त्री 4 जनवरी को पहुंचे और जल्द ही यह स्पष्ट कर दिया कि जम्मू और कश्मीर पर भारत की संप्रभुता को लेकर कोई बातचीत नहीं की जा सकती है। यह राज्य हमेशा भारत का अभिन्न अंग बना रहेगा। अयूब ख़ान के पास कश्मीर पर भारत के दृष्टिकोण को स्वीकार करने के अलावा कोई विकल्प नहीं बचा था। अगली सुबह प्रधानमंत्री शास्त्री और फील्ड मार्शल अयूब ख़ान ने आमने-सामने वार्ता की।
Thereafter, delegation-level talks began, which continued for 48 hours. When negotiations seemed to have become intractable, Premier Kosygin used his cogent diplomatic skills to narrow differences. On 10 January 1966, the Tashkent Agreement was signed by Prime Minister Shastri and President Ayub Khan.
“We tried to open a new chapter in Indo-Pakistan relationship.” इसके बाद प्रतिनिधिमंडल स्तर की वार्ता शुरू हुई, जो 48 घंटे तक चली। जब ऐसा लग रहा था कि बातचीत कठिन हो गई है तो प्रीमियर कोसिगिन ने मतभेदों को कम करने के लिए अपने कूटनीतिक कौशल का इस्तेमाल किया। 10 जनवरी 1966 को ताशकंद समझौते पर प्रधानमंत्री शास्त्री और राष्ट्रपति अयूब खान द्वारा हस्ताक्षर किए गए।

“हमने भारत और पाकिस्तान के संबंधों में एक नया अध्याय खोलने की कोशिश की है।”
The Main Features of the Tashkent Declaration were to:
- Restore normal and peaceful relations between India and Pakistan
- Promote understanding and friendly relations between their peoples
- Reaffirm their obligations, under United Nations Charter, to settle their disputes through peaceful means and not use force
- Discourage any propaganda directed against the other country
- Withdraw all armed personnel of the two countries back to the positions they held prior to
5 August 1965
- Repatriate prisoners of war ताशकंद समझौते के प्रमुख बिंदु थे :
- भारत और पाकिस्तान के बीच सामान्य और
शांतिपूर्ण संबंध बहाल हो।
- दोनों देशों के लोगों के बीच समझ और मैत्रीपूर्ण
संबंधों को बढ़ावा देना
- संयुक्त राष्ट्र चार्टर के तहत अपने विवादों को
शांतिपूर्ण तरीके से निपटाने और बल प्रयोग नहीं
करने के अपने दायित्वों की पुष्टि करना
- एक दूसरे के खिलाफ फैलाए गए किसी भी प्रचार
को हतोत्साहित करना
- दोनों देशों के सभी सशस्त्र कर्मियों को 5 अगस्त
1965 से पहले के उनके स्थानों पर वापस लेना
- युद्धबंदियों को लौटाना।
The ink was not dry on the declaration, when a tragedy sent India into shocked grief. अभी समझौते की स्याही भी सूखी नहीं थी कि एक त्रासदी ने देश को गहरे सदमे में धकेल दिया।

details.name: Nation pays homage
details.description:
10 January 1966.
The Tashkent Agreement with Pakistan had been signed, and Prime Minister Shashtri retired after a dinner for the delegations. He ate a small piece of toast and drank a glass of milk as he turned towards bed. 10 जनवरी 1966
पाकिस्तान के साथ ताशकंद समझौते पर हस्ताक्षर करके प्रधानमंत्री शास्त्री प्रतिनिधिमंडल के लिए रात्रिभोज से निवृत्त हुए। उन्होंने टोस्ट का एक छोटा टुकड़ा खाया और बिस्तर पर जाने से पहले एक गिलास दूध पिया।
He was scheduled to leave for Delhi via Afghanistan the next morning. For India’s second Prime Minister, the dawn never come. He died of a sudden heart attack in his sleep. उन्हें अगली सुबह अफगानिस्तान होते हुए दिल्ली के लिए रवाना होना था। भारत के दूसरे प्रधानमंत्री के लिए वह सुबह कभी नहीं आई। सोते हुए अचानक दिल का दौरा पड़ने से उनका निधन हो गया।
President Ayub Khan of Pakistan and Premier Aleksey Nikolayevich Kosygin of the Soviet Union carried his coffin to the special aircraft at Tashkent airport, as India awaited the return of its beloved leader with a heavy burden in its heart. पाकिस्तान के राष्ट्रपति अयूब ख़ान और सोवियत संघ के प्रधानमंत्री अलेक्सी निकोलायेविच उनका शव लेकर ताशकंद हवाई अड्डा तक गए जबकि भारत भारी मन से अपने प्रिय नेता की वापसी का इंतजार कर रहा था।
The flight landed at Delhi at two in the afternoon on 11 January. 11 जनवरी को अपराह्न 2 बजे जहाज दिल्ली में उतरा।
President Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan, Vice President Zakir Hussain and Gulzarilal Nanda, acting Prime Minister, along with the three service chiefs and a stunned nation waited for a hero, whose humility was matched by his courage. राष्ट्रपति सर्वपल्ली राधाकृष्णन, उपराष्ट्रपति जाकिर हुसैन और कार्यवाहक प्रधानमंत्री गुलजारीलाल नंदा, तीनों सेवारत सेना प्रमुख और स्तब्ध राष्ट्र ऐसे नायक की प्रतीक्षा कर रहा था जिनकी विनम्रता उनके साहस के अनुरूप थी।
He had led his country to victory in war and wanted only peace and prosperity for his people. His bereaved wife Smt. Lalita Devi fainted when Prime Minister Shastri’s body reached his residence. उन्होंने अपने देश को युद्ध में जीत दिलाई थी और वे अपने लोगों के लिए केवल शांति और समृद्धि चाहते थे। प्रधानमंत्री शास्त्री का पार्थिव शरीर उनके आवास पर पहुंचते ही उनकी शोक संतप्त पत्नी श्रीमती ललिता देवी बेहोश हो गईं।
One of the most admired leaders of the nation was cremated on 11 January 1966 at Vijay Ghat, in between the samadhis of Mahatma Gandhi and Jawaharlal Nehru. Shri Lal Bahadur Shastri had gone, but he would never be forgotten. राष्ट्र के सबसे लोकप्रिय नेताओं में से एक का अंतिम संस्कार 11 जनवरी 1966 को महात्मा गांधी और जवाहरलाल नेहरू की समाधि के बीच विजय घाट पर किया गया। श्री लाल बहादुर शास्त्री चले गए लेकिन उन्हें कभी भुलाया नहीं जा सकेगा।

details.name: Early Life and Political Journey
details.description:
Smt. Indira Gandhi…
The third Prime Minister of India!
The daughter of Smt. Kamala and Shri Jawaharlal Nehru, Indira was born on 19 November 1917.
Her grandfather Shri Motilal Nehru was amongst the finest lawyers of his generation.
Under the influence of Mahatma Gandhi, he abandoned his anglicised style of life and adopted Khadi. Shri Motilal Nehru had also served as the Congress President.
Her childhood nickname was ‘Indu’, even her toys breathed Mahatma Gandhi’s revolutionary leadership.
Her father, Jawaharlal Nehru, was her most important teacher, who imparted vast knowledge through his experiences, letters and the books he gave her to read.
12-years-old Indira Gandhi accompanied her father to the historic Lahore session of Congress, which adopted the Purna Swaraj resolution with Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru as its President.
When both her parents were arrested during the Salt Satyagraha in 1930, the 13-year-old Indira Gandhi enlisted to help Congress volunteers.
She also studied at Shanti Niketan, where she got to learn from the Gurudev Rabindranath Tagore.
Young Indira Gandhi was by her mother, Smt. Kamala Nehru’s side when she passed away in Switzerland in 1936.
Indira expressed her desire to marry her Parsi friend Feroze Jehangir Gandhi.
There were objections from traditionalists in Indira’s family, but the couple overcame all opposition and were married according to Hindu rituals on 16 March 1942.
Smt. Indira Gandhi was amongst the thousands of freedom-fighters imprisoned for participating in Mahatma Gandhi’s ‘Quit India Movement’ in 1942.
She was later released due to her failing health. Her elder son Rajiv was born in 1944, and her second son, Sanjay, was born in 1946.
Post-Independence, her father, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, was sworn in as the first Prime Minister of India. Later, Smt. Gandhi moved in as her widowed father’s official host to their new residence in Delhi.
Smt. Indira Gandhi also began to expand her involvement in party affairs.
In 1959, she was elected President of the Congress Party.
That year, she also played a decisive role in the dismissal of the Communist led state government of Kerala, and the imposition of President’s Rule. Smt. Gandhi was also active in the rehabilitation of Tibetan refugees.
In 1960, Smt. Gandhi suffered a personal loss when her husband Feroze died at the young age of 48. Four years later, her father, Shri Jawaharlal Nehru, also passed away on the 27 May 1964.
On 2 July 1964 Smt. Gandhi was inducted into the Cabinet of
Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri as the Minister for Information and Broadcasting.
On 11 January 1966 Prime Minister Shastri’s sudden demise left the country in shock.
For a brief period, acting Prime Minister Gulzari Lal Nanda took charge, however, destiny had a higher office for Smt. Gandhi in store!
She was sworn in as India’s first woman Prime Minister on 24 January 1966.
“I Indira Gandhi do solemnly affirm that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of India as by law established.”

details.name: The Nathu La Case
details.description: On 11 September 1967 Chinese troops attacked Indian posts near Nathu La on the Sikkim border. India retaliated on 10 October and proved that 1967 was not 1962.

details.name: Nationalisation of Banks
details.description: On 19 July 1969 the government nationalized the 14 largest private sector banks. Its impact was positive as bank branches spread into rural areas for the first time. There was a massive rise in deposits and investment flowing into the informal sector.

details.name: The Split in Congress
details.description: The Presidential election held in August, 1969, set the stage for the split in Congress. In this election, instead of favouring the Congress candidate, Smt. Gandhi backed Shri V.V. Giri.

details.name: Prime Minister Term: 1966 to 1975
details.description: During the period from 1966 to 1975, the country faced many issues including the food crisis and the anti-cow slaughter agitation. Major decisions of the government were associated with the devaluation of the rupee, the official languages Act, the nationalisation of banks, the nationalisation of industries, the abolition of privy purses, etc.

details.name: The War of 1971
details.description:
India’s Independence in 1947 was accompanied by partition.
Pakistan became a separate Country. Pakistan consisted of two parts, west and East.
The population of East-Pakistan, primarily Bengali, was higher than that of West Pakistan, but from the beginning the east was subjugated culturally and exploited economically by the west.
The struggle for Bangladesh Led by Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, began as a movement for justice and equality.
Sheikh Mujibur Rahman summed up the people’s demand in a powerful sentence:
“If you want to see this happen and give equal rights to Pakistanis, then you have to give Bengal their right to live.”
But instead of justice, the people of Bengal got more repression. When Sheikh Mujibur Rahman won the general elections of 1970, he was denied the constitutional right to form a majority government.
On the historic night of 25 March 1970 Sheikh Mujibur Rahman liberated his nation of Pakistani oppression by declaring the independence of Bangladesh. He was arrested. The Pakistani Army stationed in large numbers went on a murderous spree of targeted killings, rapes and loot.
More than four million terrified Bangladeshis fled from this genocide to various parts of India as refugees.
Leading to a massive humanitarian crisis, India gave shelter to the refugees in this hour of crisis.
The mood of Bangladeshis turned militant. A revolutionary people’s militia - The Mukti Bahini, rose to fight against Pakistan’s oppression.
India’s Prime Minister Smt. Indira Gandhi raised her voice to draw the attention of the world, but no power in the world community intervened to save the lives and destiny of Bangladeshis, who were being massacred in hundreds of thousands.
“This would never have been happened, if the world community had woken up to the fact when we first drew their attention to it.”
India stood by Bangladesh.
In the dusk of 3 December 1971 Pakistan launched its third war against India with air raids on Indian Airfields at Amritsar, Pathankot, Srinagar, Avantipur, Uttarlai, Jodhpur, Ambala and Agra. Simultaneously Pakistan’s ground forces started artillery shelling in Sulaimanki, Khemkaran, Poonch and other sectors.
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi spoke to the nation that evening, saying:
“A few hours ago, at around 5.30 in the evening on the third of December, Pakistan launched an attack on us. We all have to display courage, show perseverance & unity. I have no doubt that the victory will be of the people of India and the brave Indian forces.”
On that very night Indian Navy commenced Operation Trident.
Three missile boats set off from Mumbai, headed towards Pakistan’s naval base, Karachi. They kept changing course frequently to avoid radar detection.
While the crew spoke in Russian to mislead the enemy in case conversation was picked up.
Karachi came within firing range, a little before 10 PM on the night of 4 December.
At 10:43 PM, the Indian naval vessels had their target’s in sight. PNS Khaiber, a Pakistani destroyer, PNS Shah Jahan and a merchant vessel, carrying ammunition for the Pakistan forces, were destroyed by missiles.
The intrepid missile boats with their various crew now turned their attention to the Karachi harbour complex which was set ablaze with the remaining missiles. The boats then returned to Mumbai at full speed.
The killer squadron returned to Mumbai the next day to a hero’s welcome. It had not suffered a single casualty.
In the east, on the same night of 4 December, an epic naval confrontation took place in the Bay of Bengal. Pakistan had dispatched its powerful submarine, PNS Ghazi, to the vicinity of Visakhapatnam Naval Base, with the objective of destroying India’s sole aircraft carrier INS Vikrant. In a blistering counter attack, INS Rajput sank PNS Ghazi killing all its 90 seaman on board.
In a single day, the Indian Navy had created history. The fourth of December has been celebrated as Navy Day ever since.
On 6 December, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi announced before a cheering Parliament that India had recognised the new nation of Bangladesh. But the war was not yet over.
India’s strategy in the east devised under the Command of Army Chief General Sam Manekshaw and Lt. Gen. Jagjit Singh Aurora, head of the eastern command, was to neutralize the Pakistani Air Force, attack from three directions on land, set up a sea blockade in the Bay of Bengal and finally smash the “Dhaka Bowl”, the area between Jamuna, Padma and Meghna rivers where Pakistan had concentrated its defence.
The Indian Air Force quickly eliminated the enemy Air force over the Bangladeshi Airspace.
The ground war had a clear objective: to aid the Mukti Bahini and capture the capital Dhaka.
The Indian Army laid siege to Jessore, Bogra, Rangpur, Comilla, Bhairab Bazaar, Jamalpur, Mymensingh, Sylhet and Chittagong.
And thwarted Pakistani army at every point as it raced towards Dhaka. Ingenious and courageous tactics were used to cross geographical barriers like the imposing rivers in a terrain dominated by waterways.
Between 7 and 12 December 1971 several battalions of the Indian army were heli landed across the river Meghna.
On 12 December a battalion was paradropped at Tangail near Dhaka, in what is considered as an incredible achievement.
The Pakistani Army was not short of soldiers but it was hugely deficient in morale since it knew that it had been outthought and outmaneuvered. By the 15 December Indian troops and The Mukti Bahini were on the outskirts of Dhaka.
The coup de grâce was delivered by the Mukti Bahini’s rocket attack on the Governor’s House in Dhaka. Where the Pakistan Commander General A.A.K. Niyazi had been billeted. The Indian Army was just two miles away. Pakistan’s merciless game was up. General Niyazi who still had over 90,000 troops and requisite ammunition surrendered tamely to
Lt. General Jagjeet Singh Aurora on
16 December 1971.
Lance Naik Albert Ekka, Flying Officer Nirmaljit Singh Sekhon, Second Lt. Arun Khetarpal and Major Hoshiar Singh were awarded India's highest military decoration – the Param Vir Chakra.
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi told the world that an epochal war of liberation was over. Adulation for Smt. Gandhi was at its zenith.
On 10 January 1972 Sheikh Mujibur Rahman was released from a Pakistani prison. On his way back to Dhaka, he stopped over in Delhi to thank Smt. Indira Gandhi.
Sheikh Mujibur Rahman father of Bangladesh took the oath of office as the new nations first President on
12 January 1972.
The war has ended but a formal closure was needed.
Talks between India and Pakistan were scheduled to start in the last week of June 1972. Smt. Indira Gandhi reached Shimla on 27 June Pakistan’s new President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto arrived the following day.
The two leaders signed the Shimla agreement on 2 July 1972.
The two nations agreed to settle their differences by peaceful means through bilateral negotiations. Their forces returned to the international borders and the Line of Control. The third
Indo-Pak war came to a formal end.

details.name: The Emergency
details.description:
A judgement of Allahabad High Court delivered on the afternoon of 12 June 1975 shook the nation’s polity.
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi was found guilty of misusing the government’s machinery during the election campaign in her constituency Raebareli in 1971.
The court barred Smt. Gandhi from contesting elections for six years and declared her election as MP invalid. In effect, this made Smt. Gandhi’s continuation in office untenable.
Opposition parties demanded her immediate resignation, and held a massive rally on Delhi’s Ramlila grounds on 25 June 1975 under the leadership of Shri Jayaprakash Narayan, where he recited a powerful poem by Shri Ramdhari Singh ‘Dinkar’ against authoritarianism - ‘Vacate the throne, for the people are coming.’
They were unaware that in the Prime Minister’s residence a very different course of action had been initiated.
Smt. Gandhi accepted the advice of Shri Siddhartha Shankar Ray, a barrister as well as the Chief Minister of West Bengal, that a Prime Minister could ask the President of India Fakhruddin Ali Ahmad to impose an ‘Internal Emergency’ under Article 352.
On 25 June 1975 Smt. Indira Gandhi sent a letter to the President recommending Emergency without the mandatory Cabinet sanction.
The President signed the proclamation.
Freedom went into a coma; India was saddled with a virtual dictatorship. Every significant opposition leader including stalwarts like Shri Jayaprakash Narayan, Shri Morarji Desai, Chaudhary Charan Singh, Shri Chandrashekhar, Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee, Shri H.D. Deve Gowda Shri L. K. Advani, Shri Balasaheb Deoras, Shri George Fernandes, Shri Biju Patnaik, Shri Jyotirmoy Basu, Shri Parkash Singh Badal, Smt. Mrinal Gore, Shri Ramkrishna Hegde, Shri M. Venkaiah Naidu, Shri Ram Vilas Paswan, Shri Rajnath Singh, Shri Nitish Kumar, Shri Lalu Prasad Yadav, Shri Prakash Javdekar, Shri M.K Stalin and many more were taken overnight into custody under the Maintenance of Internal Security Act 1971 on fabricated charges. Many of them were kept in confinement for 19 months.
Shri Lal Krishan Advani noted in his diary: ‘June 26, 1975 may well prove the last day in the history of Indian democracy as we have understood it.” History would judge this to be too pessimistic but it reflected the mood of June 1975.
Many detainees were subjected to harsh conditions.
Shri Morarji Desai was put in solitary confinement for months.
After his arrest, Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee developed septicaemia and a slipped disc that had to be operated. He remained bedridden for months.
Shri Arun Jaitley, then president of the Delhi University Students’ Union, was detained for 19 months. The government rejected his plea to appear for his examinations under police custody on the ground that his presence in the examination centre was a threat to public order.
Shri HD Deve Gowda’s father lost his sanity due to the fear that his son might never be released and died in 1977. Shri Rajnath Singh’s mother suffered a stroke awaiting his release and passed away while he was imprisoned.
The former maharani of Jaipur, Gayatri Devi, was not allowed access to a doctor for three weeks after developing an ulcer in her mouth during her detention. The whereabouts of Rajmata of Gwalior, Vijayaraje Scindia, were not shared with her family for a month after her arrest.
On the night of 25 June, independent India experienced its first bout of draconian censorship Electricity to some printing plants was cut-off that night, so that newspapers could not be distributed the following morning. The Cabinet gave post-facto approval at a 6 AM meeting on the morning of 26 June. Congress president Dev Kant Barua equated Smt. Indira Gandhi with India.
On 27 June 1975 the President of India compounded his complicity with an order suspending a citizen’s right to move courts for protection of fundamental rights.
As the Emergency held the country in its implacable grip, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi’s younger son Sanjay moved from the sidelines to center stage in decision-making, He would become known as an extra-Constitutional authority.
Some newspapers tried ingenious ways to remind readers about the freedom that had been lost by printing quotations on freedom and fearlessness by the nations most revered icons.
In a decision heavy with irony, Smt. Gandhi’s government banned quotations from Mahatma Gandhi, Gurudev Rabindranath Tagore and even Pandit Jawahar Lal Nehru.
When the popular singer Kishore Kumar refused to join a propaganda chorus on behalf of Emergency, his songs and films were banned from the state-owned radio and television broadcasters.
Parliament amended the Constitution repeatedly to protect Smt. Gandhi from the courts.
The 38th Amendment barred judicial review of the Emergency proclamation.
The 39th Amendment prohibited the Supreme Court from hearing election petitions against the Prime Minister, Speaker of the Lok Sabha, the President and the Vice President.
The Election Laws Amendment Act passed on 5 August 1975 specifically protected Smt. Gandhi on the points for which she was held guilty by the Allahabad High Court.
The 41st Amendment bill was introduced in the Rajya Sabha on 9 August 1975 in a bid to prevent any criminal proceedings against the President, Prime Minister and Governor for any action taken during their term in office.
Rajya Sabha passed the amendment but the bill was kept on hold after some afterthought.
The most dangerous assault on liberty came through the 42nd Amendment to the Constitution, introduced in the Lok Sabha on 1 September 1976. It received the President’s assent on 18 December that year. It subverted the basic doctrine of the Constitution by legislating that changes to fundamental rights could not be questioned in any court.
It included “internal disturbance” and “disrupting harmony” in the category of “anti-national activity”. Any Member of Parliament could be disqualified by the President of India in consultation with the Election Commission, without recourse to appeal in a court of law.
The Constitutional provision on the need for a quorum in Parliament was deleted, making it technically possible for a handful of partisan MPs to pass any legislation.
The President was given the power for two years to alter or “modify” amendments passed by parliament through an executive order. “Socialist” and “Secular” were added to the preamble of the Constitution. In April 1976, the Supreme Court in the ADM Jabalpur case, upheld the Indira Gandhi government’s right to detain people without court hearings. Four justices ruled that citizens did not have the right to move the writ of habeas corpus when the Presidential Order was in force. Justice Hans Raj Khanna was the sole dissenter in the four to one judgment. Despite being the senior-most judge, he was overlooked during the appointment of the Chief Justice of India in January 1977.
Smt. Gandhi tried to justify the Emergency as an opportunity to change the social outlook and behaviour of people, and sweeten it by announcing a 20-point programme on 1 July 1975.

This programme was a mix of economic dollops to the poor and sops to the middle class, particularly to students, who had mobilized decisively against her.
One example of her attempt to change “the social outlook” was a ban on organizations like the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh and the Jamaat-e-Islami.
The people witnessed the virulent edge of dictatorship in a decision championed by Sanjay Gandhi, forcible family planning through vasectomy.
In her initial years as Prime Minister,
Smt. Gandhi had taken a measured and sensible stance on family planning, telling the sixth all-India conference on the subject in Chandigarh on 30 November 1968 that its success depended on individual citizens rather than the authority of the state.
Sterilization targets were set for Chief Ministers. Government servants, including police persons, teachers and officials were forced to produce sterilization numbers, on pain of salaries or increments being withheld or stopped. Vagrants were arbitrarily picked up and sterilized to fulfil targets.
On 6 November 1976, police barricaded Utawar village in Haryana, loaded adult and minor males into trucks, and forced them to undergo sterilization.
Similarly, government officials demolished several homes in Delhi’s Turkman Gate and other areas, which led to violence that claimed many lives.
By the end of 1976 Smt. Gandhi clearly sensed that Emergency was not sustainable and she needed the credibility of another electoral victory.
The announcement of fresh elections to the Lok Sabha in January 1977 generated country-wide excitement and hope for the revival of the democratic process.
Congress was routed in the general elections of March 1977. On 21 March 1977, Emergency was revoked by Smt. Indira Gandhi, who herself lost in her personal stronghold, Raebareli. The first non-Congress government at the Centre took office on 24 March 1977 and Shri Morarji Desai was sworn in as Prime Minister.

44th Amendment
Course correction was not enough; it was vital to ensure that a dangerous distortion of democracy like the Emergency could not happen again and accountability for corruption in government was institutionalised. On 28 July 1977 the Lokpal Bill was placed in Parliament. On 16 December 1977 “44th Amendment Bill” was introduced. The bill was meant to nullify the damage done to the constitution by introduction of 42nd amendment.
Any future Emergency would require the written advice of the full Cabinet rather than a cursory note from the Prime Minister, as had occurred in 1975. A supplementary alteration was made in the cause of economic development when the right to property was diluted from a fundamental to a legal right. The 44th Amendment was passed on 13 April 1978.

details.name: The Comeback of Smt. Indira Gandhi
details.description:
The re-election of Smt. Indira Gandhi in January 1980 was one of the most remarkable resurrections in the history of democracy.
Her Congress won 351 seats in the seventh Lok Sabha. She was sworn-in on 14 January 1980.
In her address to the nation, She said, “We have only one goal - to build a strong, self-confident, self-reliant, independent India.
Come, let us work together.”

details.name: Defence, Terrorism and Space
details.description: Smt. Gandhi made efforts to strengthen India’s defence. During the same period, the country faced four cases of hijacking, the first being in 1976, and then in 1981, 1982, and 1984. In space science, India launched its first communication satellite, Rohini-1 on 18 July 1980.

details.name: Foreign Policy
details.description: In foreign affairs, Smt. Gandhi maintained cordial relations with the Soviet Union. China and Pakistan posed the greatest security threats to the country, which she successfully addressed.

details.name: The Assam Crisis
details.description: The agitation by the All Assam Students’ Union and the All Assam Gana Sangram Parishad posed a severe challenge to Smt. Gandhi’s government.

details.name: The Punjab Problem
details.description: Between 1980 and 1984, India witnessed severe problems of seccenism in Punjab, which ravaged the state.

details.name: Demise
details.description:
On the morning of 31 October 1984 Smt. Indira Gandhi headed from her residence towards her office located in the same compound for an interview with Peter Ustinov, the celebrity actor.
She was not wearing the bulletproof vest quired by security regulations.
As she walked through her compound, two of her personal security guards, using a sten-gun and a revolver, pumped 30 bullets into her body, at precisely 9:29 am.
The two were disarmed by other security personnel, and in an ensuing scuffle, one of them was shot dead.
The surviving security guard who had shot the Prime Minister, was tried and sentenced to death and hanged in 1989.
State radio and television announced her death in the evening news of 31 October.
As soon as the news of her assassination spread, outraged mobs turned violent on the streets, leading to a human catastrophe.
On 3 November 1984 the nation wept and over a million people lined the streets, as Smt. Indira Gandhi’s body was taken in a three-and-a-half-hour procession to the banks of the Yamuna for the final rites.
Smt. Indira Gandhi’s son, Shri Rajiv Gandhi, lit her pyre.

details.name: Early Life
details.description:
Shri Morarji Ranchhodji Desai was born on 29 February 1896 in a village called Bhadeli in Gujarat.
His father Ranchhodji, headmaster of an English middle school, and his mother, Maniben, brought him up in an ethical environment of strict values.
The Desai family had limited means of earning. Shri Morarji Desai used to help his mother financially from the ten rupees he received as scholarship from Bhavnagar State.
In school, he was both athletic and studious.
He learnt Sanskrit, and he studied the great religious texts of Ramayana and Mahabharata.
Shrimad Bhagavad Gita shaped the philosophy of his life, and Mahatma Gandhi, and Bal Gangadhar Tilak inspired him greatly.

In 1918 he received his graduate degree from Wilson College in Bombay. For twelve years he worked as a Deputy Collector at Ahmedabad.
He wore a long coat, trousers and a turban as a bureaucrat.
Shri Morarji Desai was married to Gujraben.
He was tempted to join the non-cooperation movement of 1921, but worries about the education of siblings and marriage of a sister kept him back in a salaried post.
A turning point came on 12 March 1930 when Shri Morarji Desai went to see Mahatma Gandhi's Dandi March.
By the time it ended, he had decided that his place was no longer inside government. He resigned as a bureaucrat and joined Gandhiji.
Shri Morarji Desai went to jail for the first time in October 1930. Later on, he was jailed four times.
Aware of his integrity and apprehensive about his personal finances, Gandhiji once asked Morarjibhai whether he would like to return to government service, to which he replied that there was no question of him leaving the freedom struggle until India had gotten Swaraj.

details.name: Political Journey: 1937 to 1963
details.description: Shri Morarji Desai embarked on a long political journey that began in 1937, when he became a Minister in the first Congress government in Bombay. Later, he became the Chief Miniser of Bombay, and in 1956, he joined Shri Nehru's cabinet in the centre as a Finance Minister.

details.name: Political Journey: 1963 to 1975
details.description:
Shri Morarji Desai’s political journey entered a different phase with Prime Minister Shastri and later with Smt. Indira Gandhi.
The continuous conflict between him and Smt. Gandhi widened the differences between the two, and ultimately he left the Congress party.

details.name: Formation of Janata Morcha and Declaration Of Emergency
details.description: In 1975, he played a crucial role in the formation of the Janata Morcha, a coalition of opposition parties in Gujarat which formed a new government in the state. In June of the same year, an emergency was declared, and numerous politicians, including Shri Morarji Desai, were imprisoned.

details.name: Making of a Prime Minister
details.description: In the historic elections of 1977, the Janata Party came to power, and Shri Morarji Desai became Prime Minister, who was the obvious choice to head the government in terms of stature and experience.

details.name: Pledge and Victory Rally
details.description:
All Janata Party MPs and leaders assembled at Rajghat to pay homage to Mahatma Gandhi and pledged to selflessly serve the nation.
Now the time has come when we have to fulfill the promises made to the public. That is why now there is no need to speak much, but to do.
If we make any mistake while handling governance, you must not show any hesitation in telling us. There should be no fear, but you must tell us clearly.
We, whom you have chosen to govern, will be your servants.
I want to assure you only one thing that every moment we will try to become more worthy of the faith you have invested in us, that is what I can assure you. And in this we need your help, your co-operation, your sympathy and your support, you should never forget that.

details.name: Desai Style and Substance,The Nagaland Initiativeand Demonetisation
details.description: Shri Morarji Desai’s viewpoints were reflected in his decisions. He startled the nation with his initiatives in Nagaland and the demonetisation of high-value currency notes.

details.name: The Shah Commission, Lokpal Bill Introducedand The 44th Amendment Act
details.description:
The demand for accountability could not be ignored. On 28 May 1977 the government appointed a commission under Justice J.C. Shah, a former Chief Justice of India, to enquire into the Emergency and its excesses, with hearings on day-to-day basis. Oral evidence began on 28 September.
Smt. Indira Gandhi challenged the legality of the commission and did not file any statement.
Home Minister Chaudhary Charan Singh arrested Smt. Gandhi and, following a largely negative public reaction, released her within a day.
A second Congress leader who refused to depose was Shri Pranab Mukherjee, saying that he could not speak on oath without knowledge of the specific charge against him.
The Shah Commission submitted a 525-page report to the government in three phases.
The interim report of the Shah Commission appeared on 11 March 1978 describing the manner in which Emergency had been imposed. A second instalment detailed a largely unknown fact: the growing extra-Constitutional power of Smt. Gandhi’s son Sanjay.
The final report, on 6 August 1978 detailed the torture of prisoners and excesses upon the people, particularly in pursuit of plans for mass sterilization.
The Shah Commission concluded that there was no economic crisis or law and order breakdown by June 1975 which could justify the Emergency, and that it had been imposed for arbitrary political reasons. It added that the arrests of people and politicians was unwarranted, and commented that executive officers had collaborated in implementing decisions for potential career gains. It named officers who had misused their powers because of their proximity to the then Prime Minister.

details.name: Internal Political Conflict, Retirement and Last Phase
details.description:
Good governance could not contain the power struggle within the Janata government. The chasm caused internal fault lines that led the Janata Party to split by mid-1979.
Shri Morarji Desai passed away in 1995 at the age of 99.

details.name: Early Life
details.description:
Chaudhary Charan Singh was born in Noorpur village of Uttar Pradesh on
23 December 1902.
His father's name was Shri Mir Singh and mother was Smt. Netar Kaur.
He was always proud of his rural roots and made hallmark contribution to land and agricultural reforms throughout his life.
By 1925, he had received a bachelor’s degree in science and a master’s degree in law from Agra University.
He set up practice, but his preference lay in the maelstrom of our freedom movement.
By 1929, he was active in the district Congress, and acquired a high profile for his role in Ghaziabad Arya Samaj from 1931.

In 1937, he was elected as a Congress candidate to UP Legislative Assembly from Chhaprauli, a seat he held till 1974.
He was imprisoned thrice by the British during the freedom movement.

details.name: Political Journey
details.description: The political journey of Chaudhary Charan Singh started in 1929, when he joined the freedom movement. He established his name as the most popular peasant leader.

details.name: As Prime Minister
details.description:
After the Emergency, the 1977 elections brought a heterogeneous Janata Party to power, but along with power came struggle. Chaudhry Charan Singh was given the charge of Home.
The rift surfaced in June 1978 between Chaudhary Charan Singh and Shri Morarji Desai when Prime Minister Morarji Desai asked Chaudhary Charan Singh to resign.
Chaudhary Charan Singh returned to the Janata Cabinet in January 1979, with the elevated status of Deputy Prime Minister and Finance as his portfolio. Instead of restoring stability, this only spurred ambition and factionalism in the cabinet.
On 16 July 1979 Chaudhary Charan Singh, with the socialist leader Raj Narain as his strategist, broke away to form the Janata (Secular) Party.
Chaudhary Charan Singh's support increased in the Lok Sabha. He claimed majority.
“The political situation is good, nice and we are going to make a government under the leadership of Chaudhary Charan Singh.“
A secret deal with the Congress was also being negotiated by Shri Raj Narain.
On 23 July, the Congress extended the support and on 26 July, President Neelam Sanjeeva Reddy invited Charan Singh to head the new government. The same day Chaudhary Charan Singh was sworn in as the Prime Minister of India.
"I, Charan Singh, take an oath to God that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of India as established by law."
“If the country has to rise, then efforts have to be made. We all have to make efforts. I include myself in that, I include all my fellow ministers who are sitting here that we all will have to make relentless efforts, then only this country will grow.”

details.name: Resignation, 6th Lok Sabha Dissolved and Demise
details.description: Chaudhary Charan Singh formed his government with the outside support of Smt Gandhi’s Congress. But his government could not even survive for a whole month, as Smt Gandhi withdrew her support from his government. He tendered his resignation, and the Lok Sabha was dissolved.

details.name: Early Life and Political Journey
details.description:
Shri Rajiv Ratna Gandhi, son of Smt. Indira and Shri Feroze Gandhi, and grandson of Shri Jawaharlal Nehru, was born in Mumbai on 20 August 1944.
He spent his childhood in Prime Minister Nehru's official residence in Delhi, and went to Doon School in Dehradun before going to Trinity at Cambridge and then Imperial College, London for higher education.
He returned to India in 1966. Shri Rajiv Gandhi and Smt. Sonia Gandhi were married in Delhi on 25 February 1968. His passion for flying led to a job in Indian Airlines in 1970.
He was content to remain a low-profile pilot till the accidental death of his brother Sanjay in 1980. His mother, then Prime Minister, urged him to enter politics. Shri Rajiv Gandhi agreed. In 1981 he was elected to Parliament from Amethi in Uttar Pradesh and began his political life as the General Secretary of the Congress party.
His first major administrative responsibility was supervising the Asian Games in 1982, which were conducted successfully in the capital.
On 31 October 1984 while addressing a political rally in Bengal, Shri Rajiv Gandhi received a shattering message: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi had been assassinated. He returned immediately to Delhi by a special aircraft.
Within hours of the tragedy, the Congress Parliamentary Board unanimously nominated Shri Rajiv Gandhi as successor. Shri Rajiv Gandhi was sworn in as India's seventh Prime Minister by President Gyani Zail Singh at 6.45 pm on 31 October 1984.
At 41, Shri Rajiv Gandhi was the youngest Prime minister of India.
Smt. Indira Gandhi's assassination had triggered a popular outrage that manifested itself in terrifying outbursts of violence. In many cities, the fires turned into a conflagration.
While addressing a public rally on 19 Nov 1984 Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi attempted to explain this violence:
“We must remember Indira ji. We know that the hearts of the Indian people were full of anger and that for a few days, people felt India was shaking. But, whenever a big tree falls, the earth shakes."
Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi decided to seek an immediate mandate from the voters. He led Congress to an unprecedented victory in 8th Lok Sabha elections.

details.name: The Shah Bano Case
details.description: A 62-year-old lady, Shah Bano was divorced by her husband through the Triple Talaq method. She sought help from the courts. In the meantime, the Muslim Women [Protection of Rights on Divorce] Act of 1986 denied Shah Bano her sustenance.

details.name: Bhopal Gas Tragedy
details.description:
On the night of 2 and 3 December 1984 some 30 tons of Methyl Isocyanate gas from Union Carbide's pesticide factory in Bhopal spread a pall of death and destruction.
A part of the city became a silent gas chamber killing more than 15,000 people in their sleep and affecting over 600,000 others.
It was the worst industrial disaster in India's history.
As early as in 1976 trade unions had complained of the potential danger from this plant; and there had been leaks even in 1983 and 1984. But the management of this multinational remained indifferent.
The American chairman of the company Warren Martin Anderson flew to India on 7 December to take stock of the tragedy. He was taken into custody on a charge of manslaughter. Anderson was allowed to return to the United States by the government.

Union Carbide initially offered a paltry compensation of Rs. 6 Crore, while Indian authorities demanded Rs. 3960 Crore.
The dispute was eventually settled in February 1989 for a compensation of
Rs. 715 Crore. In June 2010 seven former Carbide employees were convicted of causing death by negligence and sentenced to two years of imprisonment but released on bail.
In 2001 Dow Chemical Company took over Union Carbide and stated that it was not liable for any further compensation as it was legally a new company with new ownership.
In May 2003 the government of India formally conveyed its request for the extradition of Anderson to the United States. The request was rejected in June 2004 because it did not “meet requirements of certain provisions” of the bilateral extradition treaty.
In August 2011 the central government filed another curative petition in the Supreme Court for additional compensation for the Bhopal gas tragedy victims saying that Union Carbide, now owned by Dow Chemical Company, should be directed to pay additional compensation of Rs 7,413 Crore
In October 2014 the news of Warren Anderson’s death was made public.
In February 2020, the curative petition got listed before a five-judge Constitution bench for a regular hearing.
The Welfare Commissioner for Bhopal Gas victims awarded a sum of Rs. 1517.89 crores as pro-rata compensation in 5,63,124 awarded cases till March 2021.

details.name: Shri Rajiv Gandhi and Computers
details.description:
Shri Rajiv Gandhi revolutionized communication systems through computerization. He expanded the use of computers in administration, which had been very limited till then.
“Development must relate to science, and science must relate to development. It's only then we will be getting the answers, we will be getting the speed of development that we are looking for."
Indian Railways became an exemplary instance of the benefits of technological modernisation. Passengers long used to tedious queues and a black market in tickets were delighted to discover that they could now book seats through a computerized reservation system.
A few political parties began a mass campaign against computerization, claiming that it would reduce jobs and sneering that, computers did not sit well on bullock carts. Their protests were ignored.

details.name: The Punjab Accord, the Assam Accordand the Mizo Peace Accord
details.description: The separatist movements had paralyzed states of Punjab, Assam and Mizoram. Shri Rajiv Gandhi made successful efforts to establish peace in these regions by signing peace accords with the respective leaders of these states.

details.name: Operation Black Thunder
details.description: Operation Black Thunder was initiated by the Rajiv Gandhi government in order to drive the extremist groups from the Golden Temple. The operations were completed with the surrender of a number of secessionists.

details.name: Foreign Policy
details.description: In foreign policy, Shri Rajiv Gandhi strengthened bilateral engagements across the globe. He raised international awareness about Pakistan’s role in supporting terrorism in Punjab and Jammu and Kashmir. He developed warm relations with the US and Soviet Russia.

details.name: Bofors Gun
details.description: The country signed a contract with the Swedish company Bofors in 1986. An allegation of bribes being paid to Congress leaders landed the government in trouble. The issue tarnished the image of the government, which became one of the main causes of the party’s defeat in the next general elections.

details.name: The Ganga Action Plan
details.description: With the objective of minimizing pollution and improving the water quality of India’s venerated river, Ganga, Shri Rajiv Gandhi announced the Ganga Action Plan in 1986.

details.name: Demise
details.description:
Shri Rajiv Gandhi was campaigning in Tamil Nadu on 21 May 1991 during the 10th general election.
At around 10 pm he reached Sriperumbudur, where crowds of enthusiastic supporters surged to see him, and many tried to reach him. There were separate enclosures for men and women. Shri Gandhi first greeted supporters in the men’s section and then moved towards the women’s section as he made his way to the dais to deliver a speech.
A young lady, who would later be identified as Dhanu, bowed down before Shri Rajiv Gandhi, as if trying to touch his feet reverently. As Rajiv Gandhi bent towards her, she activated a powerful bomb that had been hidden below her waist. The triggered explosive killed Rajiv Gandhi instantly, even as it took the life of Dhanu and 14 others including 9 policemen and left 43 others grievously injured. Dhanu was a suicide bomber. She had achieved her mission: the brutal assassination of the young Rajiv Gandhi.
Dhanu was a member of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE), the separatist militant organisation which was then in the middle of an active war against the Sri Lanka state. LTTE was was deeply worried about Shri Rajiv Gandhi’s possible victory and return to office after the 1991 general elections. As Prime Minister, Rajiv Gandhi had sent the Indian Peace Keeping Force (IPKF) to intervene in Sri Lanka. In the process the IPKF had engaged in combat with LTTE before Prime Minister V.P. Singh recalled the force to India in 1990. The LTTE was apprehensive that if Rajiv Gandhi returned as Prime Minister after the elections, he would send the Indian Army back into Sri Lanka.
Rajiv Gandhi, the young Prime Minister who dreamt of generational change and modernisation, was cremated on the banks of the Yamuna in Delhi on 24 May 1991. He was 46 years old.

details.name: Early Life and Political Journey
details.description: Shri V.P. Singh was born in a princely family of Daiya Estate of Prayagraj and was adopted by the Raja of Manda. He was schooled in Prayagraj, Dehradun and Varanasi and went to Allahabad University and Pune University for higher education. His political career started in 1955, and in 1957 he joined the Bhoodan-Gramdan Movement of Acharya Vinoba Bhave. His stature in Congress party hierarchy started to rise from 1969.

details.name: Making of a Prime Minister
details.description:
Congress won 197 seats in the 9th Lok Sabha, the V.P. Singh-led National Front had 143 and BJP 85 seats.
Shri Vishwanath Pratap Singh, leader of the Janata Dal and National Front, formed the government with the support of BJP and some regional parties.
He was sworn in as Prime Minister of India on 2 December 1989.
On 3 December 1989 Prime Minister Singh addressed the nation for the first time.
“The voice of the government will be voice of farmers, labours and youth. If power is sword, it will be wielded on behalf of the poor and toiling masses. A nation is not a map on a piece of paper. It lives in the hearts of the people. And if hearts are divided, the nation is divided. We will not allow this to happen. There will be a national effort to resolve Punjab, Jammu and Kashmir, Ram Janmabhoomi-Babri Masjid issues.
We will do our best to ensure the power is not confined to the corridor of the secretarial and its four walls but reaches to the chaupals and the mohallas. We will fulfill the dreams of Rammanohar Lohia and Jayaprakash ji. We shall bring forward the legislation for genuine Panchyati Raj.”

details.name: Challenges
details.description: As Prime Minister, Shri V.P. Singh had to face aggressive separatist movements in Punjab and Kashmir, which badly affected the law and order of these states.

details.name: The Mandal Commission
details.description:
The Mandal Commission had been set up by former Prime Minister Morarji Desai's Janata Party government on 1 January 1979 under the chairmanship of Shri B.P. Mandal and submitted its report to the government on 31 December 1980.
The governments led by Smt. Indira Gandhi and later Shri Rajiv Gandhi, in office between 1980 and 1989, did not act on the report.
The Janata Dal included a commitment to accept its recommendations in its election manifesto.
On 7 August 1990 Prime Minister V.P. Singh announced the most important decision of his tenure: Implementation of Mandal Commission’s report.
It recommended reservation of 27% of jobs in the government and public sector for the socially and educationally backward classes.

The consequent political tremors were felt across the country.
While the backward classes rallied wholeheartedly behind the decision, others led protests and hartals in many cities. Agitators burnt hundreds of government vehicles, buses and trains.
The protests took an ugly turn when youths in Delhi, Hissar, Sirsa, Ambala, Lucknow, Gwalior, Kota, Ghaziabad and other cities set themselves on fire.
The Army had to be called out in Chandigarh, Ambala, Sirsa, Kurukshetra, Rohtak and several other cities.
A few days later, on Independence Day, Prime Minister Singh said while addressing the nation:
"Today, the country is faced with dual challenges, separatism on one side and violence on the other. A decision was taken by the government recently that backward classes should be given a place in government jobs and the public sector. We want to give them an opportunity in the structure of power, and decision-making to run the country, make it better.”
Shri V.P. Singh was of the clear view that it is not possible to reduce the 27% reservation for socially and educationally backward classes and 22.5% for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes.
He proposed to Parliament that the impoverished should get additional reservation of 5 to 10% on an economic basis, irrespective of caste.
He later suggested a further 5 to 10 percent reservation for the economically weaker sections within the ‘upper castes’.
Prime Minister V.P. Singh did not leave anyone in doubt about his commitment to the Mandal Commission.

“I wish to make it clear that should a situation arise in which I have to choose between a cause that I believe in so intensely, and my chair, I will not hesitate for an instant to choose the former.”
Several court petitions were filed both in support of and against the Mandal Commission following the controversy that erupted after its recommendations were implemented. In 1992, the OBC quota was adopted in several central government institutions, and the education quota was implemented in 2006.

details.name: The National Commission for Women Act, the Prasar Bharati Bill, Kuwait Airliftand Fall of the Government
details.description: The V.P. Singh government introduced a Bill in the Lok Sabha to constitute a commission for women at the national level, which paved the way for the setting up of the National Commission for Women. The government also passed the Prasar Bharti Bill in order to establish a Broadcasting Corporation of India. During the first Gulf War, when Iraq invaded Kuwait, Air India operated many flights to airlift a sizeable Indian community stranded in Kuwait. In November 1990 Prime Minister Vishwanath Pratap Singh resigned after losing a vote of confidence in the Lok Sabha.

details.name: Demise
details.description: On 27 November 2008 Shri V.P. Singh passed away in Delhi.

details.name: Early Life and Political Journey
details.description:
Shri Chandra Shekhar was born on 1 July 1927 in Ibrahimpatti, Ballia, Uttar Pradesh in a farmer’s family.
His mother's name was Smt. Draupadi Devi and father was Shri Sadanand Singh.
His education began in the local village primary school from where he moved to Dayanand Anglo-Vedic (D.A.V.) School at Mau, Azamgarh.
In 1945 he completed his matriculation from Jeevan Ram High School Azamgarh.
In 1949 he graduated with a bachelors in arts from Satish Chandra Degree College, Ballia.
From 1950-51 he pursued his Masters in Political Science from Allahabad University.
Thereafter he enrolled for a Ph.D from Banaras Hindu University in 1952.
As a student-activist, he organised meetings for socialist leaders on campus and began writing in local newspapers on current issues
As a schoolboy, Shri Chandra Shekhar had been enthused by Mahatma Gandhi’s call, in 1942, to the British to Quit India.
As a young man, Shri Chandra Shekhar was deeply influenced by the ideas of socialist leaders: Shri Jayaprakash Narayan, Shri Acharya Narendra Dev and Shri Ram Manohar Lohia.
The radical Shri Chandra Shekhar dropped his surname, which denoted his caste. In 1944, he married Duja Devi and they had two sons.
In 1952, upon completing his Masters, he joined the Socialist Party and became secretary of the District Socialist Party.
Within a year, he was elected the Joint Secretary of the Uttar Pradesh State Praja Socialist Party.
In 1955-56, he took over as the General Secretary.
He contributed regularly to a publication titled ‘Sangharsh’, which was devoted to socialist causes.
In 1962 he was elected to the Rajya Sabha from Uttar Pradesh from Praja Socialist Party.
In 1965 he joined the Indian National Congress under Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri’s urging.
In 1967 he was elected General Secretary of the Congress Parliamentary Party when Smt. Indira Gandhi was Prime Minister.
In Congress, Shri Chandra Shekhar became the natural leader of a group known as the ‘Young Turks’ for their conviction, courage and integrity.
They were ready to challenge the party line, if they felt it compromised issues, such as social injustice or poverty alleviation.
In 1969, Shri Chandra Shekhar founded and edited, ‘Young Indian’, a weekly published from Delhi which was forced to close during the Emergency.
In February 1989, it resumed publication with Shri Chandra Shekhar as Chairman of its Editorial Advisory Board.
Shri Chandra Shekhar left Congress after Smt. Indira Gandhi imposed the authoritarian emergency in June 1975.
He was arrested under the Maintenance of Internal Security Act 1975 and kept first in Rohtak jail and then shifted to Chandigarh and Patiala jails. During this period, he wrote the acclaimed ‘Meri Jail Diary’.
In 1977, his dynamism and established eminence made Shri Chandra Shekhar the first President of the newly formed Janata Party.
“Colleagues and friends, I am extremely grateful to the leaders of the Janata Party and to all those colleagues who have elected me to this position of great responsibility.”
In 1977, Shri Chandra Shekhar played a stellar role in the victory of the Janata Party and its coming to power. He was elected to the Lok Sabha for the first time from his home constituency, Ballia in 1977.
In 1979 Janata party split and was defeated. In 1980, Shri Chandra Shekhar managed to retain his Lok Sabha seat at Ballia, despite the Indira wave.

details.name: Bharat Yatra
details.description:
Shri Chandra Shekhar sought to organise the political space with a marathon walk from Kanyakumari to Delhi called
the - ‘Bharat Yatra’.
Between 6 January and 25 June 1983
Shri Chandra Shekhar walked a distance of approximately 4,260 kms. He walked 20 kilometres a day. Thousands of social workers travelled with him.
Bharat Yatra Centres were set up in Kerala, Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, Maharashtra, Madhya Pradesh, Gujarat, Uttar Pradesh and Haryana.
To nurture people-oriented development projects, Shri Chandra Shekhar identified five critical village requirements:

1. Drinking water for every village
2. Steps to end malnutrition among children and expectant mothers
3. Education for all
4. Solutions to the problems of Adivasis and Dalits
5. Communal harmony
For nearly six months till it reached Delhi on 25 June 1983 the Padayatra was a continuous procession.

details.name: As Prime Minister
details.description: In November 1990, Shri Chandra Shekhar formed a new political party. During the same period, the allies of the VP Singh government withdrew their support from the government. Backed by the Congress party, Shri Chandra Shekhar became the new Prime Minister of the country.

details.name: Economic Crisis
details.description: Shri Chandra Shekhar became Prime Minister amidst a sea of troubles, as there were rising inflation, a balance of payments problem, and rising oil prices exacerbated by Iraq’s invasion of Kuwait in August 1990.

details.name: Fall of the Government

details.name: Early Life
details.description:
Shri Pamulaparti Venkata Narasimha Rao was born on 28 June 1921 at his maternal grandfather’s house in a village called Lakhnepalli at Warangal, in the Princely State of Hyderabad.
His home was in Vangara, in Karimnagar district where his parents, Rukmabayamma and P. Sitaram Rao, lived.
Their ancestors had migrated to this village from Pamulaparti in Medak and they used Pamulaparti as a geographical patronymic in all their names.
As a child, he was adopted by relatives, a wealthy, childless couple, Ratnabayamma and P. Ranga Rao.
He was in Pamulaparti when he married Satyamma.
Rao, eager for higher education went to Osmania University to take a BA degree, and then to Hislop College in Nagpur and Fergusson College in Pune for a master’s degree in law.
As a young man in the 1940s he co-edited a weekly magazine called Kakatiya Patrika, before moving into legal practice as a junior in the chambers of Burgula Ramakrishna Rao, who would become chief minister of Hyderabad in March 1952.
The last Nizam of Hyderabad, Osman Ali Khan, or Asaf Jah VII, filled with delusions of grandeur, thought he could keep Hyderabad a feudal fiefdom even after India won independence from British rule in August 1947.
Shri. Narasimha Rao joined the “Vande Mataram” liberation struggle against the Nizam, which was led by Swami Ramananda Tirth, an educationist, reformer, spiritualist and president of the Hyderabad State Congress; the Swami Ramananda Tirth became Rao’s mentor.
The Nizam was driven out by armed action initiated by India’s home minister Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel in 1948 and Hyderabad became one of the states of the Union of India.

details.name: Political Journey
details.description: Shri P.V. Narasimha Rao’s political endeavours started with the "Vande Mataram" liberation struggle. In 1957, he became an MLA. He was included in the Andhra Cabinet and, afterwords he became the Chief Minister of the state. Later he was included in the cabinets of Smt. Gandhi and Shri Rajiv Gandhi.

details.name: Economic Reforms
details.description: Prime Minister, Shri P.V. Narasimha Rao, championed liberalization, privatization and globalization, thereby leading the economy to flourish. He heralded the end of the license-quota raj, opened the economy to domestic entrepreneurs, encouraged foreign direct investment (FDI). All these factors led to a surge in growth rate.

details.name: Foreign Policy
details.description:
The Soviet Union collapsed in 1991, the year Shri Narasimha Rao became Prime Minister, changing the strategic landscape which had been in place since the Second World War, Altering the political map of Central Asia, Caucasus and Eastern Europe and creating new challenges for Indian foreign policy.
Prime Minister Rao protected India’s traditional friendship with Moscow, even as he built new bridges with Washington. He sent a senior colleague, Siddhartha Shankar Ray, as ambassador to Washington between 1992 and 1996.
Prime Minister Rao’s most dramatic innovation was in India’s ties with Israel.
Shri Rao changed decades of hesitancy by establishing full diplomatic relations with Israel.
Look East Policy
A second initiative would reap a similarly productive harvest over the long haul. Rao initiated a “Look East” policy to strengthen relations with Japan, the Republic of Korea and South East Asia. Rao became the first Prime Minister of India to visit South Korea.
During a banquet in Seoul on 10 October 1993, Shri Rao said:
”India provides a market for manufactured products which is potentially amongst the largest in the world. Private foreign investment in India has gone up sharply in the last two years. To take advantage of the new opportunities which are opening up, we would welcome more Korean business to come to India and take part in this process.”
Significant investments were made in India by Japanese and South Korean multinationals as a consequence.
Rao also visited Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore. The Prime Minister of Singapore Goh Chok Tong responded to India’s ‘Look East’ policy by asking ‘ASEAN’ (the Association of Southeast Asian Nations) nations to ‘Look West’ meaning India.
India-China
In an important breakthrough, Prime Minister Narasimha Rao and Chinese Premier Li Peng signed the Agreement on the Maintenance of Border Peace and Tranquillity along the Line of Actual Control [LAC] on 7 September 1993.
The two countries agreed to reduce troop levels compatible with friendly and good relations, undertake confidence building measures and provide notification of troop movements.
They also assured each other that they would resolve the boundary dispute peacefully through friendly consultations.

details.name: Missile Programme
details.description: During the tenure of Prime Minister, Shri Narasimha Rao, India’s missile programme made rapid strides. In this period, indigenously-made Prithvi-I missile and long-range Agni-I missile were successfully test launched.

details.name: Challenges
details.description: Terrorist attacks and multiple blasts in Mumbai, as well as increased violence in Jammu and Kashmir and Punjab, posed significant challenges to the Rao government. Another challenge came from Ayodhya when on 6 December 1992 several activists entered the disputed site of Shri Ram’s birthplace.

details.name: Panchayati Raj
details.description: In an effort to strengthen the democracy at grassroots level, the government, under the leadership of the Prime Minister, Shri Narasimha Rao, introduced the Panchayati Raj representing 73rd and 74th Amendments to the Constitution.

details.name: A New Era of Indian Television
details.description: A new era in Indian television started during the term of Prime Minister Shri Rao. Communication satellites were launched to make all-India transmission of Doordarshan’s Metro channel possible. With the liberalisation of the entertainment markets, international private channels were also permitted to telecast their programmes in the country.

details.name: Early Life
details.description:
The 12th Prime Minister of India, Shri Inder Kumar Gujral, was born on 4 December 1919 in Jhelum, in undivided Punjab in British India.
His father Shri Avtar Narain Gujral, a prominent lawyer, was also a reformer inspired by the Arya Samaj and the leadership of Lala Lajpat Rai. Public service was in the family blood. Shri Inder Kumar Gujral’s mother, Smt. Pushpa Gujral, worked for the emancipation of women and the education of underprivileged children throughout her life. Both were passionate participants in the freedom movement.
Shri Inder Kumar Gujral was just 12 when the 23-year-old nationalist Bhagat Singh was martyred at Lahore Central Jail for killing of a British police officer, John Saunders.
The martyr became a national hero. The young Inder Kumar Gujral became disillusioned with Mahatma Gandhi because of the latter’s tepid attitude towards Shaheed Bhagat Singh; the Mahatma would not condone violence even in the cause of India’s freedom. Shri Inder Kumar Gujral’s rising spirit of nationalism would not be contained; as a teenager he led a procession of young boys shouting anti-British slogans.
Bhagat Singh’s socialist ideology also left an impact. While in college, Inder Kumar Gujral joined the Communist Party of India (CPI) and became the president of the Students’ Union and the general secretary of the Punjab Students’ Federation.
In his autobiography Shri Gujral wrote, “I began my university-level education in DAV College. It was arduous for me to cope with the change in the medium of instruction. At the school level it was Urdu medium, and the switchover to English came as a sort of a cultural shock. I added to the hardship by joining the science course, which was beyond my comprehension.
As a result I lost one year. I joined Hailey College of Commerce and finally Forman Christian College to pursuea Master’s degree in economics.”
This enabled him to take up chartered accountancy.
Shri Inder Kumar Gujral broke away from the Communist Party when CPI followed the Moscow line in the Second World War, after Hitler invaded the Soviet Union, and became an ally of the British in the war effort. Shri Gujral, however, continued to work alongside the CPI-sponsored ‘Friends of the Soviet Union’ [formed in 1927 as part of the Soviet mobilization of international support].
Shri Inder Kumar Gujral was among those freedom-fighters who were imprisoned by the British for protests against the colonial rule. He was sent to the Lahore Borstal Jail for leading an “unlawful assembly of students”.
In August 1942, Shri Inder Kumar Gujral joined demonstrations following Gandhiji’s “Quit India” call, he was acquitted only after a long legal battle. After university, Shri Inder Kumar Gujral went back to Jhelum to join the family timber business. It was also time to settle down; in 1945, he married his classmate, Sheil, in Lahore.
When freedom came in August 1947
Shri Inder Kumar Gujaral’s father, Shri Avtar Narain Gujral, was a member of the Pakistan Constituent Assembly. But along with the millions shattered by partition, the Gujrals joined the great migration to India, leaving their ancestral home in what had become Pakistan, and finding refuge in Delhi.
