details.name: Early Life and Political Journey: 16 May to 1 June 1996
details.description:
Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee was born on 25 December 1924 in Shinde Ki Chhawani, Gwalior. His father, Krishna Bihari Vajpayee, was a school teacher; his mother, Krishna Devi, a homemaker.
Even as a child, he loved writing poetry, a passion that he nurtured throughout his life. Earning widespread admiration, He was India’s first poet Prime minister.
As a schoolboy, Atal Bihari Vajpayee was deeply influenced by Baba Khanwalkar, who was in charge of training recruits to the Rashtriya Swayam Sevak Sangh.
He joined the local RSS Shakha, and continued his activism on the college campus.
He graduated from Victoria College, Gwalior and completed his Master’s degree in Political Science from DAV College, Kanpur. Mahatma Gandhi’s epic challenge to British rule in 1942 inspired the young Vajpayee to participate in the
'Quit India' movement along with his elder brother, Prem Bihari.
Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee found an extraordinary mentor in Pandit Deen Dayal Upadhyay, who recognized his potential and gave him charge of the movement’s journals. In 1947 Pandit Deen Dayal Upadhyay made him editor of a new monthly magazine called Rashtra Dharma. This was followed by editorship of a daily Dainik Swadesh.
On 21 October 1951 the eminent national leader Shri Syama Prasad Mookerjee founded the Bhartiya Jana Sangh (BJS). Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee was appointed as sahayak, or personal and political secretary, a crucial responsibility.
Respectful to his elders and charming and friendly to his peers the young man made an immediate impact on political circles. Popularly known as ‘Atalji’, he became the party’s national secretary in 1955. Two years later, after the second general elections, Shri Vajpayee entered the Lok Sabha from Balrampur.

He entered the Rajya Sabha from Uttar Pradesh in 1962.
After the death of Pandit Deen Dayal Upadhyay, Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee succeeded him as the President of Jana Sangh at the young age of 43.
Vajpayee ji was among the first leaders to be arrested when Emergency was imposed in June 1975. He wrote some of his best poetry during his incarceration.
He was released in January 1977. The Congress was defeated in the general election of March 1977. The Janta Government was formed.
Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee entered office for the first time in 1977 as Minister for External Affairs. He became the first person to a speech in Hindi at the United Nations General Assembly in 1977.
“In India, We have always believed in this concept that the whole world is one family. Here we are not thinking about the power and importance of nations. The prestige and progress of the common man are of far greater importance to us.”
The collapse of Janata Party in 1980, became an opportunity for the rebirth of Jan Sangha in a new avatar as Bhartiya Janta Party.
On 6 April 1980 with Shri Vajpayee as its first president. The party symbol was a Lotus.
“The darkness will pass, The sun will rise, The lotus will bloom.”
BJP suffered a debacle in 1984 general elections following the assassination of Prime Minister Smt. Indira Gandhi. Shri Vajpayee lost in Gwalior.
It was from such margins that BJP’s leaders rebuilt the party into a national force.
From just two seats in 1984, BJP jumped to 85 Lok Sabha seats in 1989, Shri Lal Krishna Advani was the President. In the 1991 general elections BJP increased its tally to 119 seats in the Lok Sabha.
On 25 January 1992 Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee was conferred with the Padma Bhushan for distinguished public service. Shri P.V. Narsimha Rao was the then Prime Minister. He was also declared ‘Best Parliamentarian’ that year.
In 1995, BJP formally named Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee as its candidate for Prime Minister. The party’s slogan for the 1996 elections was resonant: Abki Baari Atal Bihari.
BJP won an unprecedented 161 seats in the Lok Sabha in 1996 elections; for the first time, it had won more seats than Congress, which managed only 140 seats. BJP became the largest single party in the House; along with allies it had a bloc of 187 MPs in the House, far short of the 272 needed for a clear majority.
Respecting Constitutional propriety, President Shankar Dayal Sharma gave BJP the first opportunity to form a government.
Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee was sworn in as Prime Minister of India on 16 May 1996. He did not have a majority but, as he candidly told Parliament, he would never do anything unethical to patch together one.
“The game of power will continue, governments will rise and fall, parties will born and disappear. Above it all, the country must stay shining, its democracy must remain immortal.”
For the next two years democracy seemed to be in a difficult test. Two governments were sworn in but could not survive. Necessitating fresh elections in February 1998. This time the verdict was unambiguous. BJP improved its tally to 182 seats and it’s 24 party - National Democratic Alliance won 286 seats, a majority.

On 15 March 1998 Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee became Prime Minister of India for the second time.

“I, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, do swear in the name of God that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of India as by law established.”

details.name: Operation Shakti
details.description:
11 May 1998
Pokhran Atomic Range, Rajasthan.
3:45 PM
Operation Shakti.
It was a top-secret mission. Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee did not share this decision with Cabinet colleagues until the last minute.Preparations were ready for early May;but atmospheric conditions became favourable only on 11 May 1998,coincidentally the day of Buddha Purnima.On this day India became a nuclear power.
“ Today at 15: 45 hours,India conducted three underground nuclear tests in the Pokhran range.”
With these tests India became the sixth formal nuclear power,altering the strategic map of Asia and confirming India’ s technological and scientific promise.The world acknowledged that India’ s tests had been completely indigenous.
Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee affirmed India’ s commitment on‘ no first use’ nuclear weapons.
“ We have formally announced a policy of No - First - Use and non - use against non - nuclear weapons states.As Hon’ ble Members are aware,a policy of no - first - use with a minimum nuclear deterrent implies deployment of assets in a manner that ensures survivability and capacity of an adequate response.”
There was instant pressure from USA upon India.Washington imposed sanctions.
Three of the five permanent members of the UN Security Council: USA,China and Britain,opposed Shri Vajpayee’ s decision.Australia,Canada,Germany and Sweden joined USA in the sanction’ s regime.Russia and France were supportive towards India.
Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee showed exceptional ability at handling to multiest relationships with excellent diplomacy and unwavering commitment to India’ s national interests.
He wrote to President Clinton explaining the rational for his decision,India had to correct the strategic balance with China.Shri Vajpayee wrote: 
“ I have been deeply concerned at the deteriorating security environment,especially the nuclear environment,faced by India for some years past.We have an overt nuclear weapon state on our borders,a state which committed armed aggression against India in 1962. Although our relations with that country have improved in the last decade or so an atmosphere of distrust persists mainly due to the unresolved border question.”
Between June 1998 and September 2000 Minister for External Affairs Jaswant Singh and US Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott met 14 times in seven countries across three continents.
This comprehensive engagement persuaded USA that Shri Vajpayee’ s decision was a rational correction of a historic wrong, and laid the foundation of future strategic and economic cooperation between the two countries.President Clinton 's visit to India in March 2000, the first American president in over two decades, marked the acceptance of India as a nuclear power.
“Two nations conceived in liberty, each finding strength in its diversity, each seeing in the other a reflection of its own aspiration for a more humane and just world.”
“No Price is high enough when it comes to securing national interests.”

details.name: 1999: Crack in Coalition, No-Confidence Motion, Dissolution of Lok Sabha and General Elections, 1999
Operation Vijay
details.description:
In early May 1999, Pakistan resorted once again to military aggression with a full-scale assault by its troops in the Himalayan mountain ranges above Kargil situated between at altitude of 16,000 and 18,000 ft.
Pakistan had betrayed the Lahore Declaration promising a peaceful resolution of problems within weeks of signing it, proving once again its continuing commitment to clandestine terrorism, deception and war.
By the third week of May, Pakistani troops had established entrenched positions in the high ranges,
putting Srinagar-Leh Highway, India’s supply route to Siachen Glacier at the mercy of their guns. Pakistani troops armed with anti-aircraft guns and Stringer missiles, occupied 132 Indian positions in Mushko, Drass, Kaksar and Batalik sectors under the cover of heavy artillery shelling.
On 26 May 1999 Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee ordered the start of "Operation Vijay", a counteroffensive by the Indian Army and Indian Air Force. He said:
“The world has seen that we want peace. Now the world will see our demonstration of power to protect peace. There is no doubt about the conclusion of the battle. Our victory is definite and we will achieve it.“
More than 20,000 thousand Indian military and paramilitary personnel were deployed to defeat Pakistan’s aggression with support from powerful long range Bofors artillery guns as a counter to Pak’s artillery bombardment.
The Indian Airforce counter-attacked through “Operation Safed Sagar” with MiG-21, MiG-23, MiG-27, MiG-29, Mirage 2000, Jaguars and Mi17 armed helicopters.
On 30 May 1999 while addressing the nation, Prime Minister Vajpayee said, "I want to tell every soldier that the entire country stands with you, every Indian is grateful to you. This whole operation has been thrust upon us. The whole world is watching how our brave armed forces are defending the Motherland on inhospitable hilly terrain and at grave risk to their lives.
On 12 June Pakistan’s foreign minister Sartaj Aziz came to Delhi for talks, and was told that there was nothing to discuss until Pakistani intruders withdrew completely from Indian territory.
The defining moment of the war was the battle on the Tololing summit. On 13 June, Indian soldiers proudly hoisted the Indian tricolor on the Tololing peak.
On 15 June President Bill Clinton of the United States urged Pakistan, the aggressor state, to withdraw. Islamabad, still living under the illusion that it possessed the military advantage, ignored the American President.
On 20 June, the Indian Army captured the strategically important Point 5140 from Pakistani occupiers.
The battle for Tiger Hill, one of the highest peaks in the area was the most challenging part of the war.
By 4 July, the Indian flag was once again flying over Tiger Hill. Pakistan had been humiliated yet again by the valor and patriotism of the Indian Armed forces and determined political leadership.
President Clinton summoned Pakistan’s Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif to Washington. On 5 July, Nawaz Sharif accepted defeat. He announced a total retreat. On 14 July 1999 Prime Minister Vajpayee declared that Operation Vijay had been a complete success.
26 July is celebrated as Kargil Vijay Diwas.
In a shocking display of petulance, Pakistan refused to accept the bodies of its own soldiers killed in battle. The Indian Army performed their last rites.
Captain Vikram Batra, Lieutenant Manoj Kumar Pandey, Subedar Major Yogendra Singh Yadav and Rifleman Sanjay Kumar were awarded India’s highest military decoration Param Vir Chakra.

details.name: Education for All
details.description:
"It's morning, the bird has fled the nest, and the school bell has rang."
The Constitution 86th Amendment act made education a fundamental right of every child, giving free and compulsory education of all children between the ages of 6-14 years who had been denied education largely due to poverty.
"Kids are going to school; we're getting ready as well; we'll go to school; we'll go to school together."
The government also launched the Sarva Siksha Abhiyan in 2001 to address all aspects of elementary education.
Including:
 Institutional reforms
 Sustainable Financing
 Community Ownership
 Institution capacity building
 Thrust on quality
 Preparation of district elementary education plan
It covered 10 lakh elementary centres, reaching about 20 crore children.

details.name: Golden Quadrilateral
details.description:
The Vajpayee government started an ambitious project to connect the principal metro cities Delhi, Mumbai, Chennai and Kolkata through a highway Quadrilateral. This was the biggest road project since independence and modernise the communication map of India.
“The work has commenced on Rs. 54 Thousand Crore National Highway Development Project.”
Prime Minister Vajpayee laid the foundation stone for the project on the 6 January 1999 with the aim of completion by 2006 but effective work began only in 2001 because of delays in land acquisition and other constraint. The project was completed by 2012 creating a multiplier effect on the rural economy. This was complemented by the Rural Road Connectivity (RRC) program.
As the Golden Quadrilateral linked major trading centers. New businesses flourished around the country.
In addition, the Vajpayee Government launched Pradhanmantri Gram Sadak Yojna on 25 December 2000. A 100% centrally sponsored scheme for paved rural connectivity between villages with a population of 500 or more, and those with a population of 250 or more in hilly and desert regions.
“Even after 50 years of independence, there were about 2 lakh villages which were not accessible by roads. For the first time, the Centre has started the Pradhan Mantri Gram Sadak Yojana to connect these villages with good roads”.
They provided access not just to cities and villages, it also provided millions of deprived Indians, access to better education, healthcare, markets and business centers. It created a strong foundation for economic growth. Even today people are reaping the rewards of work envisaged in the first decade of 21st Century.

details.name: Hijacking and Terrorism
details.description:
The Dilemma

In the last week of 1999, Prime Minister Vajpayee was severely tested by terrorism. On 24 December 1999 Indian Airlines flight IC 814, which had taken off from Kathmandu at 4:10 pm for New Delhi with 179 passengers and 15 crew on-board, was hijacked by the Pakistan based terrorist group, Harkat-ul-Mujahideen.
At 4.55 pm, the five hijackers disguised as passengers, ordered the pilot, Captain Devi Saran to fly to Pakistan. The pilot, claiming that the plane was low on fuel landed at Amritsar. This gave Indian authorities an opportunity to immobilize the aircraft. But there was inordinate delay over a decision by the crisis management team in Delhi.
After 40 minutes on the Amritsar airport tarmac, terrorists forced the pilot to fly to Lahore. Pakistan initially refused the aircraft permission to land, but eventually allowed the plane to refuel at Lahore before it left for the Dubai military airport. Meanwhile, the barbaric terrorists killed one passenger, Rupan Katyal, who got into an altercation with them. After prolonged negotiations, 27 passengers, most of them women and children were released at Dubai.
The hijackers then took the plane to Kandahar in Afghanistan, where it landed at 8:30 am on 25 December 1999. In Kandahar, armed forces of the Taliban government surrounded the plane and its senior leaders opened negotiations with Delhi on behalf of the hijackers, who demanded the release of a terrorist kingpin, Maulana Masood Azhar, then in an Indian prison, along with other terrorists.
Prime Minister Vajpayee was in a great dilemma. On 31 December 1999, seven days after the hijacking, the Indian government decided to release Maulana Masood Azhar, Umar Sheikh and Mohammed Zargar in exchange for all the passengers and crew. In an unusual move, foreign minister Jaswant Singh went to Kandahar in the aircraft taking the three released terrorists, to ensure that the deal was honoured.
“Surely the time has come for the world to confront this evil, to act in concert and crush it. The battle against terrorism can be won by all nations acting together by outdoing the terrorist in patience, in technology, in strength, in intelligence. India shall join hands across nations to rid the world of this crime against humanity. Let this be our first resolution for the new century.”

The Agra Summit

Pakistan’s military defeat in Kargil had a dramatic impact on the country’s domestic power equations. On 15 October 1999 Army chief General Pervez Musharraf, who had led and lost the Kargil war, led a coup to oust Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif and imposed Army rule over Pakistan.
In Delhi Prime Minister Vajpayee watched, waited and made the strategic decision to reach out to Pakistan's generals in yet another bid for a peaceful resolution of the long conflict. As he put it: “I have been telling my friends in Pakistan - we have been fighting for 50 years now. How much blood needs to be shed more? Let us fight poverty, unemployment and backwardness.”
His efforts led to an India-Pakistan summit at Agra between 14 and 16 July 2001.
General Musharraf brought a four point proposal for peace:
1: Demilitarisation and phased withdrawal of troops;
2: Free movement across the existing Line of Control in Jammu and Kashmir;
3: No independence for Jammu and Kashmir;
4: Creation of a joint mechanism for governance involving India, Pakistan and Jammu and Kashmir.
Prime Minister Vajpayee could never accept any dilution of India's sovereignty over Jammu and Kashmir or any agreement which did not condemn terrorism in unequivocal terms. The Agra Summit collapsed.
Speaking at the first Conference on Interaction and Confidence Building Measures in Asia (CICA) Summit at Almaty on 4 June 2002, Shri Vajpayee said:
“As far as India-Pakistan dialogue is concerned, it is India which has always taken the initiative for it. In the space of last 4 years, I have been to Lahore, and invited Mr. President Musharraf to Agra. We have repeatedly said that we are willing to discuss all issues with Pakistan including Jammu & Kashmir, but for that cross-border terrorism has to end.”

The Attack on Parliament

Pakistan reverted back to terrorism. Five months after the Agra Summit, Pakistan's state-sponsored terrorist groups selected an audacious target for yet another barbaric assault.
On 13 December 2001 at 11:40 in the morning, five Pakistani terrorists armed with AK47 rifles and grenades entered the Parliament House complex in an Ambassador car fitted with a red light and a fake Home Ministry sticker to deceive security.
Reaching the main building within moments, they opened random fire with AK47 rifles and pistols for over 30 minutes. Eight security personnel and a gardener were killed and 15 others were injured before the five terrorists were shot dead.
Later Prime Minister Vajpayee informed Parliament that the perpetrators belonged to the Lashkar-e-Taiba and Jaish-e-Mohammad. The mastermind of the operation was Maulana Masood Azhar, founder of Jaish-e-Mohammad.
He explained: “Why Parliament House? Parliament House was chosen after careful consideration. It is the heart of this republic and it represents entire India.
Shri Vajpayee prepared a wide-front retaliation, including targeting a huge training camp for terrorists located deep inside Pakistan Occupied Kashmir (POK).

On 15th December 2001, he ordered the mobilisation of Indian troops on the Pakistan border, called Operation Parakram, India’s largest troop mobilisation since the 1971 Bangladesh liberation war.
"Operation Parakram ended after a ten-month stand-off between India and Pakistan in October 2002."

details.name: Formation of three new states and The Jammu and Kashmir Peace Initiative
Poet Bid's Goodbye
details.description:
In his final address to the nation, Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee mentioned:

"The World has started recognising India, as the world’s largest democracy and an emerging economic power...
No longer wait for Gas and Telephone connection now. Mobile Phone subscribers have increased from 8 lakh to one and half crores.
Software Export has increased from Eight Thousand Crore to Fifty Thousand Crore. Before 2008, India will send its own spacecraft to the moon. It will be named as Chandrayaan-1.
Because of Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan, no child, especially girl child will be deprived of Primary Education.
Today there are more than Ten lakh women members in Panchayats & Municipalities.
His personality had many facets: orator, poet, journalist, mass leader, parliamentarian and statesman. He started writing poetry in school; his range extended across patriotism, religion, love, satire and social commentary.
कदम मिलाकर चलना होगा
बाधाएं आती हैं आएं
घिरें प्रलय की घोर घटाएं,
पांवों के नीचे अंगारे,
सर पर बरसें यदि ज्वालाएं,
निज हाथों से हंसते-हंसते,
आग लगाकर जलना होगा।
कदम मिलाकर चलना होगा।
Poetry became the creative nourishment that helped him sustain the dark days of detention during the Emergency.
Those poems were later published as Kaidi Kavi Rai ki Kundaliyan
Further collections of his poems were released: Nayi Disha in 1999, and Samvedna in 2002.
His masterpiece was ‘Aao Phir Se Diya Jalaye’:
आओ फिर से दिया जलाएं
भरी दुपहरी में अंधियारा
सूरज परछाई से हारा
अंतरतम का नेह निचोड़ें
बुझी हुई बाती सुलगाएं
आओ फिर से दिया जलाएं
हम पड़ाव को समझें मंज़िल
हम पड़ाव को समझें मंज़िल
लक्ष्य हुआ आंखों से ओझल
वर्तमान के मोहजाल में
आने वाला कल न भुलाएं
आओ फिर से दिया जलाएं
आहुति बाकी, यज्ञ अधूरा
आहुति बाकी, यज्ञ अधूरा
अपनों के विघ्नों ने घेरा
अंतिम जय का वज्र बनाने
नव दधीचि हड्डियां गलाएं
आओ फिर से दिया जलाएं
आओ फिर से दिया जलाएं
Vajpayee ji passed away on 16 August 2018. Tributes poured in from all over the world. Prime Minster Narendra Modi walked beside the cortege on its final journey. Atal Bihari Vajpayee was cremated with full state honours at Rashtriya Smriti Sthal in Delhi.

details.name: Early Life and Political Journey
details.description:
Glittering Life
Dr. Manmohan Singh Kohli was born on 26 September 1932 in Gah, a village in the Chakwal district of Punjab which became part of Pakistan after partition.
Tragically, his mother, Smt. Amrit Kaur, died due to typhoid when he was still a child, and he was raised by his grandparents Smt. Jamna Devi and Shri Sant Singh.
At the age of 11, he was sent to the Khalsa High School for Boys in Peshawar, where his father Gurmukh Singh, a clerk, was posted.
Academic Brilliance
He was preparing for his matriculation examination in 1947 when the havoc of partition upturned his life.
His family migrated to eastern Punjab in June 1947, eventually settling down in Amritsar.
Dr. Manmohan Singh dropped ‘Kohli’, a caste designation, from his name.
He joined the Hindu College in Amritsar and then Punjab University to study economics at both graduate and post-graduate levels.
His academic career took him from Punjab to the University of Cambridge, where he earned a First-Class Honours degree in Economics in 1957. Meanwhile, he won the Wright Prize for excellent performance in St. John's College, Cambridge. He followed this with a Doctorate in Philosophy in Economics from Nuffield College at Oxford University in 1962.
He married Gursharan Kaur; the couple had three daughters.
Dr. Singh’s academic credentials were burnished by the years he spent on the faculty of Punjab University and Delhi school of Economics.
New Journey
Between 1966 and 1969, Dr. Singh worked for UNCTAD - United Nations Conference on Trade and Development and then joined the Government of India as an advisor to the Ministry of Foreign Trade.
In 1972 he became Chief Economic Adviser to the Ministry of Finance and then Secretary in the Finance Ministry in 1976.
Success at home and abroad
Between 1980 and 1982, Dr. Manmohan Singh was a member-secretary of the Planning Commission, after which he was appointed Governor of the Reserve Bank of India until 1985 where he initiated early banking reforms. He was also, simultaneously, Alternate Governor for India at the IMF.
And a member of the Economic Advisory Council to the Prime Minister in 1983-84.
He returned to Delhi as Deputy Chairman of the Planning Commission in January 1985.
In 1987, President Julius Nyerere of Tanzania invited Dr. Singh to become Secretary-General of the South Commission; the same year, he was awarded the Padma Vibhushan.
In 1990 Dr. Manmohan Singh became Economic Adviser to Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar.
One of the last decisions taken by Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar was to appoint him Chairman of the University Grants Commission.
Destiny had much more in store for
Dr. Singh.
Doctor of Ailing Economy
In June 1991, P.V. Narasimha Rao was sworn in as Prime Minister amid a monumental economic crisis.
The new Prime Minister surprised his political colleagues by appointing
Dr. Manmohan Singh as Finance Minister to help steer the country out of this economic crisis.
Dr. Singh proclaimed a new model of economic reforms for India known as the LPG, or 'Liberalisation, Privatisation and Globalisation.'
During his term as Finance Minister,
Dr. Singh skilfully implemented Prime Minister Rao’s decisions, including devaluation, lending his own scholarship and expertise to the process.
Recognition
Dr. Manmohan Singh received a large number of awards for his stellar role as Finance Minister, including…
1997 - Lokmanya Tilak Award and Justice K.S. Hegde Foundation Award
1997 - Nikkei Asia Prize for Regional Growth
1999 - H. H. Kanchi Sri Paramacharya Award
2000 - Annasaheb Chirmule Award
Dr. Singh in the House
Dr. Manmohan Singh's significant contribution to the Congress government headed by Prime Minister Rao was recognised by his party after the defeat in the 1996 elections, when Dr. Singh became a front-bench leader in the Rajya Sabha.
He was first elected to the Upper House from Assam in 1991, and he was re-elected in 1995, 2001, 2007, 2013 and then again in 2019.
Between 1 August 1996 and 4 December 1997 Dr. Singh was chairman of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Commerce in the Rajya Sabha.

When a coalition led by the BJP came to office in 1998, and remained in power till 2004, Dr. Singh was Leader of the Opposition in the Rajya Sabha.
Oath as a Prime Minister
On 22 May 2004 Dr. Manmohan Singh took oath as the 13th Prime Minister of country.
“I, Manmohan Singh, do swear in the name of God and by law established that I’ll uphold the sovereignty and integrity of India…

details.name: India-United States Civil Nuclear Energy Cooperation
details.description:
US had imposed sanctions on India after Pokhran 1 nuclear tests of 1974 which denied India the benefits of nuclear trade.
To free India from these restrictions Prime Minister Manmohan Singh raised the issue in the US Senate during a bilateral summit in Washington in July 2005.
“India’s track record in nuclear non-proliferation is impeccable.”
In the same visit Prime Minister Manmohan Singh and President George W. Bush announced their agreement to enter into a civil nuclear deal.
“It’s not easy job for the Prime minister to achieve this agreement, I understand, it’s not easy for American President to achieve this agreement. But it's a necessary agreement. It's one that will help both our peoples. Again, I applaud you for your courage and your leadership.”
The deal was finalized in subsequent visits and formally signed on 2 March 2006. The administration of President Bush worked towards a waiver from the Nuclear Suppliers Group which would permit other countries to supply nuclear material to India despite the fact that India had not signed the Nuclear Proliferation Treaty.
The waiver was granted. India separated its military nuclear facilities from civilian and placed the latter under the International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards.
On 18 August 2008 the IAEA Board of Governors approved the India-specific clauses.
An Indo-US nuclear cooperation agreement was finalized on 10 October 2008 after approval from the US Congress.
Due to Dr. Manmohan Singh’s diplomacy, India was able to join three major international regimes: The Missile Technology Control Regime, Wassenaar Arrangement and Australia Group.
Dr. Manmohan Singh thanked President Bush and said:
“For 34 years, India has suffered from a nuclear apathy, we have not been able to trade in nuclear material, nuclear reactors, nuclear raw materials, and when this restrictive regime ends, I think a great deal of credit will go to president Bush and for this I am very grateful to you Mr. President.”

details.name: The Attacks of 26/11 and the National Investigation Agency Act (NIA)
details.description:
On the night of 26 November 2008 two rubber dinghies docked on Mumbai’s coastline.
Local fishermen near the beach became suspicious at the sight of ten men with heavy backpacks getting out of the boats.
But before they could raise the alarm, the men boarded two taxis and left.
It was a beginning of an unforgettable episode of ruthless and barbaric terrorist couch. The men split into groups and headed towards separate targets.
At 9.45 PM one unit reached The Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Terminus, Mumbai's biggest railway station.
Stepping onto the platforms two terrorists armed with AK-47 opened indiscriminate fire, killing 52 people within minutes.
Many more lives would have been lost had not railway announcer Vishnu Zende used the public address system to warn innocent Mubaikers of the terrorist havoc.
A second unit stopped at on Leopold Café, a popular café in Colaba, and opened random fire, killing 11 people inside. And then, headed towards the Nariman House, which has a Jewish Chabad House with an educational centre and a synagogue which it reached by 10:30 PM.
The terrorists killed six people, including the Jewish priest and his pregnant wife.
Their two-year-old son Moshe had a miraculous escape. Thanks to his brave Indian nanny, who escaped with the child in her arms.
Between 9.45 and 9.50 PM, a third contingent of four terrorists stormed Mumbai's most iconic hotel, the Taj Mahal Palace.
The Taj was, as usual, full of Indian and foreign guests.
Upon entering the hotel, the terrorists gunned down dozens of people in the lobby and then headed to the upper floors, where they started selectively killing people in their rooms.
American and Israeli citizens were particularly targeted.
The presence of mind and courage of the hotel staff, who refused to leave their hotel, helped many guests and visiting diners to flee the horror.
In a short time, the terrorists created a hideout on the upper floor of the hotel from where they continued to unleash terror. They were also in regular touch with their handlers in Karachi, Pakistan from this temporary sanctuary.
Around the same time, between 9:35 and 10 pm, a fourth unit of 2 gunmen reached another five-star hotel, the Oberoi-Trident-Towers. They entered the restaurant and opened fire on scores of people having dinner.
The two terrorists of the first module moved from the railway station to Cama-Hospital and Metro-Cinema.
Before stepping out of taxies, the terrorists hid bombs in the vehicles they had used, which exploded later when the unsuspecting taxies had taken other passengers.
Mumbai Police personnel mobilized rapidly as they became aware of this unprecedented calamity.
Mr. Hemant Karkare, Chief of the Anti-Terrorist Team, Additional Superintendent Ashok Kamte and Inspector of Police Vijay Salaskar laid down their lives while taking on the terrorists near Cama Hospital.
The two terrorists from the first module fled in a police van.
They were stopped by the police at Worli. One of the terrorists was killed inside the vehicle.
An unarmed Asst. Sub Inspector Tukaram Omble, caught the gun’s barrel of the terrorist and refused to let go even after 4 rounds were emptied into his body.
Until his colleagues managed to capture the assailant.
This was how the sole surviving perpetrator of the attack was taken into the police custody. His name was Ajmal Amir Kasab.
In the early hours of 27 November, the National Security Guards launched Operation Black Tornado. The operation began by NSG commandos surrounding the Taj Mahal and the Oberoi-Trident hotels and entering them. Simultaneously, a helicopter with a crack team headed towards Nariman House.
Commandos rappelled down from the hovering helicopter, stormed the Chabad House, killed both the terrorists hidden their and rescued hostages.
At almost the same time, both the terrorists in the Oberoi-Trident were killed.
The situation at the Taj was more perilous.
Terrorists set fire to the first, fourth, fifth and sixth floors.
The NSG smashed the windows, and the evacuation of guests using ladders began amid a raging fire.
Gradually, the NSG commandos started advancing and engaged with the terrorists on the upper floors.
Who made it their last defence, using hand grenades that left many injured.
The commandos stepped into the heavy smoke and fire to rescue their wounded comrades and eliminate the last four terrorists by 8 AM on the morning of 29 November.
The three-day long terror attack claimed 167 lives of Indians as well as visitors from Australia, Canada, England, France, Germany, Holland, Italy, Israel, Japan, Malaysia, Mauritius, Mexico, Singapore, Thailand and the United States.
“This is not the first time that the enemies of our country have tried to spoil the atmosphere of peace, happiness and prosperity. These mischievous people have not yet understood that we Indians are one and will remain one. They have not yet understood that we will never allow their nefarious intentions to succeed.”
Indian security agencies had also recorded satellite phone and cellular phone conversations between the terrorists and their handlers in Karachi.
It was confirmed that the terrorist organisation Lashkar-e-Taiba (LeT) had planned the Mumbai terror attack.
On 3 December 2008, India declared Zakiur Rehman Lakhvi, the co-founder of Lashkar-e-Taiba, as the mastermind of the Mumbai attack.
Pakistan’s role in the attack was acknowledged at a global level.
Dr. Manmohan Singh’s government initiated institutional reforms to improve India’s security systems.
On 31 December 2008, Parliament passed the National Investigation Agency (NIA) Act.
Following an open trial, on 3 May 2010 Ajmal Kasab was convicted of murder, conspiracy and waging war on India and on 6 May 2010 he was sentenced to death by hanging.

details.name:
Entire Journey:
Early Life & Political Journey till Demise
details.description:
In the Planning Commission (1950-53)
As Deputy Chairman of the Planning Commission, Shri Gulzarilal Nanda prepared the first Five Year Plan within one year. It focused on country’s capacity building for economic growth with largest budget allocation of 27.1% for irrigation and energy and 24% for transport and communication.
It led to setting up of a Central Committee on land reforms with policies on Prohibition which found its way into the Second Five Year Plan.
He established a non-political, non-governmental organization called Bharat Sewak Samaj in 1952 for public participation towards achieving plan targets.
He said: “The objective of starting the Bharat Sewak Samaj was to generate a new spirit of Lok Shakti among the people and create a sense of responsibility to enable them to participate in the reconstruction of the country”.
Working within the P.C. Mahalanobis framework for rapid industrialization, Shri Gulzarilal Nanda made the Plan objectives more realistic with an assessment of available financial resources.
As a Minister of Planning and Deputy Chairman of the Planning Commission he maintained a bridge between planning and effective execution.
In the Union Cabinet (1953-1962)
Shri Gulzarilal Nanda was Union Minister of Planning and Union Minister of Irrigation and Power from 1953 to 1957. During his tenure integrated river development, flood control, effective utilisation of irrigation capacities were undertaken.
Implementation of river valley projects and dam projects like Bhakra Nangal, Hirakud, Damodar Valley, Koyna and Chambal were taken up.
From 1957 to 1962 Shri Gulzarilal Nanda was Union Minister of Labour and Employment. He worked on education of labour and participation of labour in management securing minimum wages for workers and bonus benefits.
He secured acceptance and adoption of a Code of Common Practices in addition to an acceptance of voluntary agreement principle for arbitration.
In the Planning Commission (1960-1963)
Between 1960 and 1963, Shri Gulzarilal Nanda was Deputy Chairman of the Planning Commission. The Third Five Year Plan was prepared in his tenure which focused on the social objectives of the Constitution.
The introduction to the plan document highlighted:
• Progress towards Socialism
• Equal Opportunities
• Distribution of Economic Power
• Disparities in Income
• Economic and Social Integration
As the Union Home Minister (1963 - 1966)
Between 1963 and 1965 Shri Gulzarilal Nanda was the Union Home Minister. In 1965 he created a new paramilitary force – the Border Security Force (BSF) – as a constituent of the Central Armed Police Forces of the Union of India. Cross-border infiltration from East and West Pakistan and communal conflicts posed a serious threat.
He supported greater integration of Jammu and Kashmir with the Union of India through Articles 356 and 357 of the Constitution. He managed the Punjabi Suba movement (spearheaded by Master Tara Singh and Sant Fateh Singh) aimed at the creation of a separate Punjabi majority province out of the erstwhile East Punjab province.

Shri Gulzarilal Nanda served as the Prime Minister for two brief terms.
He was sworn in as the Prime Minister following the demise of Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru in 1964. He was in office from 27 May 1964 until 09 June 1964.
In 1966, following the sudden demise of Shri Lal Bahadur Shastri at Tashkent, he was sworn in as the Prime Minister. He was in office from 11 January 1966 to 24 January 1966.
The situation was sensitive and volatile during both terms. Particularly, in the aftermath of the war with China (1962) and Pakistan (1965) respectively.

Shri Gulzarilal Nanda was bestowed the Bharat Ratna in 1997. He passed away on 15 January 1998 at the age of 99 in Ahmedabad.
On his demise, President K.R. Narayanan said; “The nation had lost an irreplaceable link with the Gandhian age of struggle and sacrifice.”

details.name: Makers of the Indian Constitution
details.description:
\The Constitution is the supreme law of India. It lays down the framework defining fundamental political principles, establishes the structure, powers, and duties of the Legislature, the Judiciary and the Executive and sets out fundamental rights, directive principles of state policy, and citizens’ duties.
It is the longest written constitution of any sovereign country in the world, containing in its original form 395 articles and 8 schedules to which additions have been made through subsequent amendments. Today, the Constitution has 395 articles and 12 schedules.
The Constituent Assembly of India was elected to draft the Constitution of India. Following India’s Independence, the members of the Constituent Assembly served as the nation’s first Parliament. The Assembly met for the first time in New Delhi on 9 December 1946 at 11.00 am in the Constitution Hall, now the Central Hall of Parliament.
Dr. Sachchidananda Sinha was the temporary chairman of the Constituent Assembly when it met for the first time. Dr. Rajendra Prasad was then elected the President of the Constituent Assembly and would later become the first President of India.
On 13 December 1946 Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru introduced the Objectives Resolution in the Constituent Assembly that laid down fundamental principles of the Constitution. On 22 January 1947 the Constituent Assembly unanimously adopted the Objectives Resolution.
In its meeting on 14 August 1947, a proposal for forming various committees was presented, including the Committee on Fundamental Rights, the Union Powers Committee and Union Constitution Committee. On 29 August 1947, the Drafting Committee was appointed with Dr. BR Ambedkar as the chairman and
6 other members assisted by a Constitutional advisor Sir Benegal Narsing Rau.
Dr. B.R. Ambedkar, Dr. Rajendra Prasad, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, Maulana Abul Kalam Azad, Shri C. Rajagopalachari, Shri Kanaiyalal Munshi, Shri G.V. Mavalankar, Dr. Syama Prasad Mookerjee and Shri Balwant Rai Mehta were some of the important figures of the assembly.
15 women members of the Constituent Assembly played a seminal role in all its deliberations: Smt. Ammu Swaminathan, Smt. Dakshayani Velaayudhan, Begum Aizaz Rasul, Smt. G.Durgabai, Smt. Hansa Mehta, Smt. Kamla Chaudhari, Smt. Leela Roy, Smt. Malati Devi Chowdhury, Smt. Kumari Annie Mascarene, Rajkumari Amrit Kaur, Smt. Renuka Ray, Smt. Sarojini Naidu, Smt. Sucheta Kriplani, Smt. Vijayalakshami Pandit and Smt. Purnima Banerjee.

details.name: Making of the Constitution
details.description:
A Draft Constitution was prepared by the Committee and submitted to the Assembly which was debated on 4 November 1947 and over 2000 amendments were moved over a period of 2 years.
The Assembly met in sessions open to the public for 165 days spread over 2 years 11 months and 17 days before adopting the Constitution. The total expenditure incurred during this process was 64 lakh Rupees.

details.name: Dr. B.R. Ambedkar’s Address
details.description:
25 November 1949 Dr. Ambedkar gave a memorable and historic speech in which he made several significant observations. He said:
“The Constitution can provide only the organs of State such as the Legislature, the Executive and the Judiciary. The factors of which the working of those organs of the State depends are the people and the political parties they will set up as their instruments to carry out their wishes and their politics.
We must make our political democracy a social democracy as well. Political democracy cannot last unless there lies at the base of it social democracy. What does social democracy mean?
It means a way of life which recognises liberty, equality and fraternity as the principles of life. These principles of liberty, equality and fraternity as the principles of life. These principles of liberty, equality and fraternity are not to be treated as separate items in a trinity.
They form a union of trinity in the sense that to divorce one from the other is to defeat the very purpose of democracy. Liberty cannot be divorced from equality, equality cannot be divorced from liberty. Nor can liberty and equality be divorced from fraternity.
The credit that is given to me does not really belong to me. It belongs partly to Sir B. N. Rau, the Constitutional Adviser to the Constituent Assembly who prepared a rough draft of the Constitution for the consideration of the Drafting Committee.
A part of the credit must go to the members of the Drafting Committee who, as I have said, have sat for 141 days and without whose ingenuity to devise new formulae and capacity to tolerate and to accommodate different points of view, the task of framing the Constitution could not have come to so successful a conclusion.
Much greater, share of the credit must go to Mr. S. N. Mukherjee, the Chief Draftsman of the Constitution. His ability to put the most intricate proposals in the simplest and clearest legal form can rarely be equaled, nor his capacity for hard work.



He has been an acquisition to the Assembly. Without his help, this Assembly would have taken many more years to finalise the Constitution. I must not omit to mention the members of the staff working under Mr. Mukherjee.
For, I know how hard they have worked and how long they have toiled sometimes even beyond midnight.
I want to thank them all for their effort and their co-operation.”

details.name: From Enactment to Execution
details.description:
On 26 November 1949 the process was completed, and the Constituent Assembly adopted the Constitution. It came into effect on 26 January 1950, a day celebrated as India’s Republic Day. This date was chosen to commemorate the Purna Swaraj declaration of Independence of 1930. With its adoption, the Union of India officially became the modern and contemporary Republic of India and it replaced the Government of India Act of 1935 as the country’s fundamental governing document. The Constituent Assembly became the provisional Parliament of India and continued to exist until the first elections under the new Constitution took place in 1952.
The Preamble of the Constitution declared India as a sovereign, democratic republic, which would secure for all its citizens Justice ‘social, economic and political and Liberty, Equality and Fraternity. The words “Socialist” and “Secular” were added to the Preamble in 1976 through a constitutional amendment.

details.name: Interim Government
details.description:
On 2 September 1946 Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru was sworn in as head of an Interim Government as preparations began for the transfer of power from colonial Britain to an independent India.
On this occasion, Pandit Nehru sought to contradict the impression that real authority continued to lie with the British Viceroy. He stated: “We shall take full part in international conferences as a free nation, with our own policy, and not as a satellite of another nation.
Too long have we been passive spectators of events, the playthings of others. The initiative comes to our people now and we shall make the history of our choice”.
Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru held charge of External Affairs and Commonwealth Relations and took decisions that established an independent foreign policy.
In stark contrast to British policy, India lodged a complaint in the United Nations against the treatment of Indians in South Africa.
Pandit Nehru and Aung San, the Premier of the British Crown Colony of Burma, discussed the withdrawal of 12,000 Indian troops from Burma.
In a direct challenge to European colonialism, Pandit Nehru inaugurated The Asian Relations Conference in New Delhi on 23 March 1946 with the intention of promoting cooperation among Asian people.
Pandit Nehru authorised the import of foodgrains from countries like Burma, Argentina and Australia, and introduced schemes to conserve food resources and manage food distribution.
Navigating the country through turbulent conditions, the Interim Governmen introduced a Price Fixing Committee and a permanent Tariff Board. The government drafted a new defence policy and initiated important legislative measures such as the Industrial Disputes Bill and the amendment to the Factories Act.
The decisions of the Interim Government reflected Pandit Nehru’s claim that:
“we are not just caretakers for a brief period”.
The Interim Government approved Pandit Nehru’s proposal to form a Foreign Service and Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel’s proposal for a future Indian Administrative Service.
The composition of the Interim Government changed significantly in October 1946 after the Muslim League decided to join Pandit Nehru’s Cabinet and the second-highest-ranking League politician, Nawabzada Liaquat Ali Khan, became the Finance Minister.
On 20 February 1947, British Prime Minister Clement Attlee announced the end of British Rule in India., he said, Power would be transferred into responsible Indian hands by ‘a date not later than June 1948’.
On 24 March 1947, Lord Mountbatten replaced Lord Wavell as the Viceroy of India. On 3 June 1947, Lord Mountbatten released a plan on the country's independence that partitioned of British India into two nations, India and Pakistan.

details.name: Partition 1947
details.description:
On 3 June 1947 the Viceroy, Lord Mountbatten, announced the partition of British India into two new independent dominions, India and Pakistan. The Congress Working Committee approved the Partition Plan.
Mountbatten’s plan for the ‘transfer of power’ to the two dominion governments of India and Pakistan with their own Constituent Assemblies became the basis of the Indian Independence Act 1947.
Ratified by the British Parliament and the Crown on 18 July and implemented on 14-15 August 1947, the Act also partitioned the provinces of Bengal and Punjab between the two new countries, established the office of Governor-General in India and Pakistan as representatives of the Crown and terminated the British suzerainty over the princely states with effect from 15 August 1947. The princely states could decide to join either India or Pakistan.
At the midnight hour of 14-15 August 1947, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru announced the birth of free India in the Central Hall of Parliament in the historic ‘Tryst with Destiny’ speech. “Long years ago, we made a tryst with destiny, and now the time comes when we shall redeem our pledge, not wholly or in full measure but very substantially. At the stroke of the midnight hour, when the world sleeps, India will awake to life and freedom.”
At that moment, the Father of the Nation Mahatma Gandhi was 1500 km away in Calcutta bringing peace to the riot-torn city with a saint's ultimatum: If the people did not stop violence, he would fast till his death. For the Mahatma, the joy of India’s freedom was overshadowed by the tragedy of the partition of India and the visceral violence which erupted. When All India Radio and BBC asked Gandhiji for a message on India's freedom, his response was that he had nothing to say. As havoc spread across Punjab, Bihar and Uttar Pradesh, Gandhi ensured that Bengal, a traditional cauldron of communal conflict, remained peaceful. Newspapers hailed this achievement as the "miracle of Calcutta".

details.name: War of 1947-48
details.description:
The State of Jammu & Kashmir found itself in becalmed isolation on 15 August 1947 when India attained freedom as Maharaja Hari Singh was yet to sign the Instrument of Accession. Pakistan decided to take advantage of this indecision, and tried to seize the princely state through an indirect armed assault.
On 22 October 1947 over two hundred vehicles carrying nearly 5000 tribesmen from the North West Frontier Province, guided by officers of the Pakistan Army using pseudonyms, attacked Jammu and Kashmir with the aim of capturing Srinagar before India could react. The J&K State Force headed by Brigadier Rajendra Singh was inadequate to look after the 500-kilometer-long mountainous border but managed to check the advance of the raiders by destroying a vital bridge at Uri.
Brigadier Rajendra Singh was honoured with a posthumous Maha Vir Chakra when the first Indian military honours were instituted. Wreaking havoc along the path, the raiders took out the Mohore power plant on 24 October, blacking out a virtually defenceless Srinagar. It was then that Maharaja Hari Singh fully realised the danger, and appealed to India for military assistance.
The Defence Committee of the Government of India met in New Delhi on 25 October to discuss the future course of action.
Lord Mountbatten, who became Governor-General of the Dominion of India after freedom, Prime Minister Nehru and Home Minister Sardar Patel agreed that Indian forces could intervene only when Jammu and Kashmir became legally a part of India.
Maharaja Hari Singh signed the Instrument of Accession on 26 October 1947 and the Indian army moved into action. Rarely in the history of warfare has such a military operation been put into action at such short notice or such a scale. In the early hours of 27 October 1947 over a hundred aircraft, from both military and civilian, mobilised to ferry troops, equipment and supplies to Srinagar.
Upon landing, Lt Col. Dewan Ranjit Rai, commander of an infantry battalion of 1 Sikh Regiment, learnt that the raiders had taken Baramulla and decided to confront them. The tribal force was equipped with light and medium machine guns and mortars and mines, and its officers were fully conversant with battle tactics. At the end of the first day, the Indian army pushed the invaders to a line 17 miles from Srinagar. Colonel Rai, who became a martyr, changed the course of the war and was honoured with a Maha Vir Chakra.
Royal Indian Air Force (RIAF) Dakotas from 12 Squadron and civilian planes flew missions around the clock till 161 Brigade, led by Brigadier L.P. Sen, with nearly 3000 troops from 1 Sikh, 2 Punjab, 1 Kumaon and 4 Kumaon, was fully inducted into operations. 161 Brigade was placed under the J&K Force commanded by Major General Kulwant Singh.

On 2 November 1947 Major Somnath Sharma, leading a large offensive patrol of three companies of 4 Kumon Regiment, was ambushed in Badgam by raiders.
With one hand in plaster, Major Sharma led his men in a heroic battle to save Srinagar from a counteroffensive, which was decimated by infantry and two RIAF Spitfires that strafed the enemy. Major Somnath Sharma was posthumously decorated with independent India’s first Param Vir Chakra.
Over the next few months, the raiders were pushed out of the Valley towards Baramulla by a series of successful engagements. In one of the finest tactical battles, at Shalateng on 7 November 1947, Indian forces outflanked the enemy from two sides and ended the threat to Srinagar. Moving past the raiders at the Haji Pir Pass, Lt. Col. Pritham Singh and his 1 Kumaon Regiment entered Poonch on 22 November 1947 and defended the garrison for over a year while being blockaded by raiders from all directions.
In February 1948, Brigadier Mohammed Usman, Commander of 50 Para Brigade, and his men smashed a force of 2000 raiders to capture Naushera in a bruising infantry battle. Brigadier Usman, who had refused to go to Pakistan at the time of partition, would be hailed as the Lion of Naushera. After regaining Naushera, Brigadier Usman was tragically killed in an artillery battle on 3 July 1948 and was honoured with a Maha Vir Chakra.
By March 1948, the raiders had retreated to Kargil and Leh. In May 1948 Major General KS Thimayya and Air Commodore Mehar Singh landed at Leh, at an altitude of 11,500 ft. By late July, the Indian army had taken control of the 325 km road between Manali and Leh.
In an audacious operation planned by Major General Thimayya, Stuart light tanks of the 7th Light Cavalry Regiment were dismantled in Jammu and moved to Srinagar. Two Companies of Madras Engineering Group moved the tanks across weak wooden bridges and created tank-friendly tracks up to Zojila Pass at 3500 meters above sea level in the Himalayas. On 1 November 1948 the raiders were cleared out in a combined arms assault by tanks, fighter aircraft and hand-to-hand combat. Zojila was the highest point in the recorded history of warfare in which tanks had operated.
On 21 November 1948, the Poonch garrison came under attack from the Pakistan Army, which had now joined the war in full force, supported by artillery. The year-long siege of Poonch ended on 23 November 1948 in one of the bloodiest battles fought by men of 19 Brigade and 5 Brigade.
Fought by many regiments of the Indian Armed Forces, the first bitter war between India and Pakistan, launched by Pakistan, ended with a ceasefire on 1 January 1949.

details.name: Shri Jawaharlal Nehru's Demise
details.description:
On 7 January 1964 Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru suffered a mild paralytic stroke while attending the annual Congress session in Bhubaneshwar. His physicians prescribed rest, but India’s first Prime Minister found it hard to slow down. Pandit Nehru resumed attending office in March 1964, even though he had not fully recovered. Between 23 and 26 May Pandit Nehru went on a brief vacation to Dehradun, accompanied by his daughter, Smt. Indira Gandhi, and returned in good spirits.
On 27 May 1964, Pandit Nehru suffered a sudden heart attack. Smt Indira Gandhi sent for three doctors who had been treating her father since his stroke. News of Pandit Nehru falling seriously ill began to spread. Home Minister Gulzarilal Nanda informed a sombre Lok Sabha about the Prime Minister’s health.
Despite the best efforts of the doctors and prayers of the entire nation, Pandit Nehru never regained consciousness.
“डूबे हुए हैं गम में, शौक से भरे हुए मगर तुम्हे हिम्मत से काम चलाना है इस देश का, जिस रास्ते पे पंडित जवाहरलाल नेहरु हमको चलाना चाहते थे”
India lost its first Prime Minister at the age of 74. He had led the nation for seventeen years since its independence in 1947.
On 28 May 1964, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru’s body draped in the national flag was placed on a ceremonial gun carriage by six pallbearers representing the Indian Armed Forces. The six-mile funeral process through the streets of Delhi was attended by grief-stricken Indians who came to pay their heartfelt tribute to a great leader.
Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru was cremated with full military honours at Shantivan on the banks of River Yamuna. Tributes poured in from all corners of the world, and dignitaries of several countries attended Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru’s funeral.
In his last will and testament Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru wrote:
“As my last homage to India's cultural inheritance, I am making this request that a handful of my ashes be thrown into the Ganga at Allahabad to be carried to the great ocean that washes India's shore. The major portion of my ashes should, however, be disposed of otherwise. I want these to be carried high up into the air in an aeroplane and scattered from that height over the fields where the peasants of India toil, so that they might mingle with the dust and soil of India and become an indistinguishable part of India."

details.name: Historic Speeches of Shri Jawaharlal Nehru
details.description:
“Long years ago we made a tryst with destiny, and now the time comes when we
shall redeem our pledge, not wholly or in full measure but very substantially. At
the stroke of the midnight hour, when the world sleeps, India will awake to life
and freedom. A moment comes, which comes but rarely in history, when we step
out from the old to the new, when an age ends, and when the soul of a nation long
suppressed finds utterance.
It is fitting that at this solemn moment we take the pledge of dedication to the
service of India and her people and to the still larger cause of humanity.”
“The appointed day has come - the day appointed by destiny - and India stands
forth again after long slumber and struggle, awake, vital, free and independent...
On this day, our first thoughts go to the architect of freedom, the Father of our
Nation who, embodying the old spirit of India, held aloft the torch of freedom and
lighted up the darkness that surrounds us.
We have often been unworthy followers of his, and we have strayed from his
message, but not only we, but the succeeding generations, will remember his
message and bear the imprint in their hearts of this great son of India, magnificent
in his faith and strength and courage and humility. “

details.name: New Foreign Policy and Indo China War
details.description:
On 20 October 1962, China suddenly invaded India across the disputed border along the Himalayan mountains. The Chinese offensive had been in the making for many years but despite rising instances of skirmishes, and warnings from senior generals of the Indian Army, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and his Defence Minister Shri V.K. Menon continued to nourish the illusion that China would never resort to full-scale war. Prime Minister Nehru believed that his investment in diplomacy and friendship was sufficient for the security of the nation, and defence preparedness was seriously neglected. The Prime Minister’s mistake would later be described as a “Himalayan blunder.”
The Chinese displayed their nefarious intentions as early as July 1958, when their troops occupied Khurnak Fort in Ladakh. China Pictorial, a magazine started by Mao Zedong in 1950, published a map showing parts of north-east India, Uttar Pradesh and eastern Ladakh within ‘approximate borders of China'. On a parallel front, the massive Chinese repression in Tibet left the Dalai Lama with no option but to proclaim independence and seek refuge in India. On 31 March 1959 the Tibetan spiritual leader arrived in India with thousands of his followers. Still trying to appease China, Pandit Nehru refused to condemn China and claimed that giving the Dalai Lama political asylum was reflective of India’s ancient traditions of hospitality. China, in contrast, viewed the sanctuary given to the Dalai Lama as a hostile act.
On 21 October 1959 Chinese forces opened fire at an Indian patrol near the Kongka pass, killing ten Indian police personnel and entering Eastern Ladakh. Until the autumn of 1959, Indian police personnel manned the 4000-km long Indo-Tibet border.
Chinese Premier Chou En-lai arrived in Delhi on 19 April 1960 for talks with Pandit Nehru. The two countries appointed official teams to study the boundary issue but the 600-page report submitted to the two governments in February 1961 noted the long list of conflicting positions without offering any solutions.
Chief of Army Staff General Kodandera Subayya Thimayya, who had briefly resigned in August 1959 over disagreements with Defence Minister Shri Krishna Menon, reiterated that the Indian army would be able to fight only a limited war with China because of neglect in defence preparedness. By the summer of 1961, China established posts in Chip Chap valley, Nyagzu and Dambuguru and built roads connecting them with their bases.

In March and April 1962 India established a few posts on the Depsang plains of Aksai Chin and near Daulat Beg Oldie, the strategic Air Force base in northern Ladakh. Chinese patrolling between Karakoram Pass and Kongka La had resumed and Indian posts in Chip Chap and Galwan valleys were encircled. In May 1962 China refused India’s proposal that both sides withdraw to the lines claimed by them. As China prepared for a full-scale war, the Indian government believed that such an escalation would never happen.
On 21 July 1962 Chinese troops opened fire on an Indian patrol. On 8 September, Chinese troops descended onto India's Thagla ridge in the eastern sector and there was an exchange of fire between the two armies on 20 September. On 9 October 1962 the newly appointed Indian Corps Commander, Gen B.M. Kaul, ordered Indian forces to occupy Siyang, south of Thagla ridge.
That same month, a crisis on the other side of the globe, in Cuba, gripped the world's attention as it brought America and the Soviet Union to the brink of nuclear war. With all eyes transfixed on the Cuban missile crisis, China invaded on 20 October 1962.
Moving down the western and eastern sectors with mortar and mountain artillery, the Chinese attacked heavily outnumbered Indian troops, who were pushed back despite a display of heroic courage and sacrifice on battlefields like Se La, Rezang La, and Chushul.
Prime Minister Nehru tried to lift the nation’s sagging morale by saying, “No self-respecting nation would tolerate such outrageous aggression…we can never submit or surrender to aggression. That has not been our way” Across India, the clamour for accountability at the failure of India's political leadership turned into a storm. On 31 October 1962, Prime Minister Nehru accepted Defence Minister Menon's resignation and took personal charge of the Defence portfolio.
Indians rallied in support of their armed forces during this trauma. There was an unprecedented upsurge of emotions from Kashmir to Kanyakumari as citizens donated blood for the soldiers and money and gold for the nation's defence fund.
On the night of 17 November 1962 Se La fell and on 19 November Bomdi La was taken. As India’s north-east and Bengal became vulnerable, China continued its doublespeak and accused Indian forces of aggression. Finally, Prime Minister Nehru wrote to President John F. Kennedy of the United States on 19 November 1962 requesting defence equipment, including supersonic all-weather fighter jets, to stem the Chinese aggression.
Within two days on 21 November China declared a unilateral ceasefire and stated that beginning 1 December 1962, it would withdraw its forces 20 kilometres behind the Line of Actual Control that existed on 7 November 1959. Speaking in the Lok Sabha on 10 December 1962, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru termed the Chinese invasion one of the ‘grossest acts of imperialist aggression’ and spoke of a struggle that would last for years.
The government woke up only to the urgent need for more robust security only after the trauma of this crisis: the national budget for 1963 increased Defence spending by over 133 per cent from Rs. 372 cr. to Rs. 867 cr.
The first five-year Defence Plan for the period 1964-69 presented by the new Defence Minister Shri YB Chavan envisioned the expansion of the army from 10 divisions to 21 divisions, increasing its strength from 285,000 men to 825,000 men, and expanding the Air Force from 22 combat squadrons to 45.
In March 1963, a special unconventional force called the Special Service Bureau was formed to increase surveillance and security in remote and far-flung areas along the border. It was renamed Sashastra Seema Bal in 2001.

en.pm_name: India at Independence: The British Legacy

details.name: India at Independence: The British Legacy
details.description:
The British colonisation of India, which took place in gradual phases between 1757 and 1850, followed a central strategy: the economic exploitation of a country with abundant agriculture and manufacturing, and the transfer of wealth from India to British coffers. By the time the Union Jack came down, on 15 August 1947, India's economy had been battered, and Indians had become victims of poverty, hunger, disease and repeated famines which took a toll of millions each time.
Statistics reveal the facts. According to the British economist Angus Madison, India’s share of the world GDP fell from 24.4 per cent in 1700 to 7.6 per cent in 1913 and the United Kingdom’s share rose from 2.9 per cent to 8.3 per cent in the same period. The Swiss economic historian Paul Bairoch noted that in 1750, or seven years before the decisive British victory at Plassey in Bengal, India accounted for 24.5 percent of the world manufacturing output while the United Kingdom had 1.9 percent; by 1900, India’s share had been reduced to 1.7 percent and the United Kingdom's share risen to 18.5 percent.
In the first great famine under British rule, in 1769-1770, between half and one-third of Bengal’s population died of starvation, according to reports preserved by the East India Company. In a note written to the Court of Directors of the East India Company on 3 November 1772, then Governor of Bengal, Warren Hastings, boasted how despite the death of at least one-third of the inhabitants of the province, the tax revenues were higher during the horrific disaster by the use of violence to extract money from dying and the dead. In the last great famine under the British Raj, also in Bengal in 1942-43, an estimated three million perished as food was diverted to feed British troops. The fabled wealth of India had been pillaged by her colonisers. By 1947, a once-prosperous agricultural output had been reduced to an annual production of just 50 million tonnes as sustenance for 340 million Indians.
Only about 12 percent of Indians, most of them men, were literate. Life expectancy was 32 years; medical services were virtually non-existent. More than half of all livelihoods were dependent on agriculture. Roads were a rarity and those that existed had been built, like the railways, to serve the commercial, administrative and strategic interests of India’s colonisers.
India’s textile industry, especially its handloom sector once known for producing the finest of fabrics like diaphanous muslin, sought across Europe, and patronised by the likes of French Empress Joséphine, was killed by taxation policies designed to favour the produce of Lancashire mills. Bengal added some 150 names for cloth to the English dictionary, including silk, calico, muslin, chintz, and gingham. Paul Bairoch’s study of International Industrialisation Levels from 1750 to 1980 found that import of English textiles by India increased from 1 million square yards in 1814 to 13 million square yards in 1820, 995 million square yards in 1870 and 2050 million in 1890.
India had missed the first industrial revolution because an industrialised India was not in the interest of her colonisers as it would pose a challenge to British economic dominance.
Colonial Britain squeezed revenues out of India to finance both the first and second world wars. By April 1947, Britain owed India £1.8 billion including nearly £1.3 billion in war expenditure. Instead of settling the debt, British officials proposed dividing the repayment over decades and limiting interest on the balances to as low as 0.5 percent. The British used a combination of constant negotiations on the repayment structure and interest rates, along with delays, to the release of balances that resulted in an overall adjustment of the British debt to India by nearly 60 percent. Britain once again had succeeded in protecting its interests at the expense of India, this time by sleight of hand.
The thin ruling class of British officials, officers and their comprador agents which prospered during the Raj displayed its wealth in pomp and pageantry, but behind the high life of British rule lay a nation bleeding from multiple wounds.

details.name: Parichay
details.description:
From agricultural revolution to scientific innovation.
From a famished nation in 1947 to the world's fastest growing Economy.
From satellite communication to a nuclear power.
Independent India is a story of hope, self-reliance, determination and achievement.
15 exemplary Prime Ministers have methodically built India with bold foresight by laying the foundations of progress on the values of India’s founding fathers.
The first Prime Minister Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru created new avenues for economic regeneration in both agriculture and industry with his ‘Temples of Modern India,’ dams and steel plants which became the fulcrum of new cities like Durgapur and Bhilai.
Shri Gulzarilal Nanda, the highly respected Cabinet Minister, played the important Constitutional role of being the bridge Prime Minister between his predecessor and the leader who would be elected Prime Minister by the MPs of the ruling parliamentary party.
When the nation battled with a food crisis, Shri Lal Bahadur Shastri led the way with the Green and White revolution.
When Bengalis in East Pakistan, devastated by a genocide, began a liberation war Smt. Indira Gandhi gave our neighbours sanctuary, and then took the difficult and courageous decision to support the Bangladesh liberation struggle, a decision which created history.
Shri Morarji Desai, who became Prime Minister after the Emergency, ensured that the spirit and principles of the Constitution were protected by reversing amendments made during the Emergency.
As an agrarian reformer, Chaudhary Charan Singh laid emphasis on farmers’ rights.
Nascent India found a technological avatar in Shri Rajiv Gandhi, who steered India into the era of computers.
Shri Vishwanath Pratap Singh increased the arc of reservations in jobs by implementing the Mandal Commission's recommendations.
Shri Chandra Shekhar took bold decisions designed to protect the nation's economy from freefall.
Shri P.V. Narasimha Rao did stellar service to the country through a range of liberal and liberating reforms essential for a 21st century economy.
Shri H.D. Deve Gowda and Shri Inder Kumar Gujral were leaders of integrity who helped navigate the country through a time of political crisis.
Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee fulfilled India’s dream of becoming a nuclear state, initiated nationwide infrastructure and provided exemplary leadership in the war against terrorism.
Dr. Manmohan Singh, the second Prime Minister of the new millennium, ended what has been described as a "nuclear apartheid" by signing the nuclear deal with the United States, and ensured India's place as a legitimate nuclear power.
Prime Minister Narendra Modi, determined to improve the life of every citizen, is leading India to all-around excellence through financial inclusion, affordable health care, digitisation of governance, provision of clean drinking water, electricity and sanitation to every household.
Poet or pilot, freedom fighter or young leader, economist or veteran politician, each Prime Minister has crafted India's long journey from independence to the high table of world affairs.
Let us witness Indian history through the eyes of India’s Prime Ministers.
